reviews.reviewText:
Don't miss Sarnath if you are visiting Varanasi. It's a major Buddhist archaelogical site (monasteries ruins, Buddhist temple, etc.) that has now developed into a major Buddhist pilgrimage site. There's a lot to see, and if you are an archaeology or Buddhist history enthusiast and have got the time, it's worth a day of exploration. Let me summarize what you can explore here, along with some suggestions:

1) Dhamek Stupa: It's a huge ancient (5th AD) stupa as you can see in the photos, and the main attraction of Sarnath complex. Trust me, it's something, with intricate carvings and strange ancient writings (Brahmi) on its circular wall.

2) Monastery ruins: There are ancient monastery ruins which have been excavated from ground over the century (first by British, then by Indian government). I am not very familiar with the details, but there are some important artifacts and features like Ashokan pillars etc. (on the pillar ruins, there are writings in an ancient Brahmi language).

3) Buddhist Museum: Many important items that have been excavated from the site are stored in this Museum. A must-see place.

4) There are many more noteworthy places to visit nearby,. This includes a very large and beautiful Japanese temple with a sleeping Buddha, a Myanmar-style pagoda, a huge standing Buddha statue inside a Thai monastery complex, Sarnath Buddhist temple, and many more monasteries (we had to miss few due to time constraints, especially as we had seen lots and lots of monasteries in Bodh Gaya 2 years back).

5) International crowd: You will see lots of international tourists here, especially groups from South East Asia and Far East. You will even see entire groups from those Buddhist nations meditating and chanting on the lawns near the monastery ruins. Offers a great peek into Buddhist culture.

6) Neat and well-managed: The entire Sarnath complex is very neat and well-managed. You have ticket counters, online ticket option, wheelchairs, refreshment centers, shopping stalls at the entrance, and so on.

Suggestion: Get tickets online (both Museum & Dhamek Stupa) before visiting as the queue can be quite long at the ticket counter. Also photography is allowed here, so you can take your electronic items with you.

Visiting Dhamek Stupa was a peaceful and meaningful experience. The site holds deep historical and spiritual significance, as it‚Äôs believed to be where the Buddha gave his first sermon after enlightenment.
The stupa itself is massive and beautifully built, surrounded by well-maintained gardens and other ruins that give you a sense of the area‚Äôs importance in ancient times.
There‚Äôs a quiet, reflective atmosphere, and I‚Äôd recommend taking time to walk around slowly and take it all in.
If possible, visiting with a guide or reading up a bit beforehand adds a lot to the experience. Definitely worth a visit if you‚Äôre in Sarnath or nearby Varanasi.

Journey to Sarnath and experience the profound peace of Dhamek Stupa. This ancient monument marks the spot of Buddha's first teaching, dating back to Emperor Ashoka!
‚ÄãA masterpiece of Gupta-era architecture and a pivotal site in Buddhist history. The Dhamek Stupa in Sarnath is a must-visit for history buffs and spiritual seekers.Its A very calm place for roaming around to give relax to your body and mind.

Entrance is guided by app based payment and one enters an excellent premises maintained by the Archaeological Survey of India. Contemporary association is of the National Emblem and Ashoka Lion having originated at this venue. Light and Sound Show in the evening is great and links all the dots in following Lord Buddhas life.

üåü Sarnath ‚Äì Where History Whispers & Nature Breathes üåü
Just a few kilometers from the chaos of Varanasi lies Sarnath ‚Äì a calm, soul-stirring sanctuary where Lord Buddha gave his first sermon. If you‚Äôre chasing peace, wisdom, or just a break from city noise, this is your spot.
üõï Dhamek Stupa: Massive, timeless, and meditative. You can almost hear the chants in the wind.
üèõÔ∏è Sarnath Archaeological Museum: A treasure trove of ancient relics. Don‚Äôt miss the Lion Capital of Ashoka ‚Äì India‚Äôs national emblem. The museum is compact but loaded with powerful history. Perfect for curious minds and history geeks.
üåç Global Buddhist Temples: Walk through temples built by Japan, Thailand, Tibet, and more ‚Äì each one a work of art and culture.
ü¶Å Sarnath Deer Park (Zoo): Ideal for families and kids. Small, clean, and peaceful with a variety of animals including deer (of course!), peacocks, and some exotic birds. Great for a slow walk after temple visits.
üìú Mulagandha Kuti Vihar: A beautiful modern temple with stunning frescoes and a serene garden for meditation.
üí° Pro Tips:
‚úîÔ∏è Early morning or late afternoon is best for peaceful vibes & photos.
‚úîÔ∏è Entry fees are nominal ‚Äì carry some cash.
‚úîÔ∏è Avoid loud noises ‚Äì it‚Äôs a sacred zone.

‚ú® Verdict:
Sarnath isn‚Äôt just a day trip. It‚Äôs a soul trip. It teaches you that silence can be powerful, and peace can be found

A good place to visit if you are interested in the related subject. A very big museum contains so many buddha sculpture on the sand stone dated back to 6th-7th century. There is also a excavation place also where many old buildings, stupas are found.
Ticket is also too cheap 5 rupees for the museum and total 30rupees for the whole place.

It‚Äôs once in a life time experience to visit the origin of Buddhist teaching point.  The location is well organized with good information.  It‚Äôs clean and good for just sit there reading and mediation.  The security also active walking with alert when visitors acting inappropriate.

Overview

+13
Sarnath is a highly regarded Buddhist pilgrimage site and historical location, known for its serene atmosphere, well-maintained grounds, and significant Buddhist monuments like the Dhamek Stupa. Visitors often describe it as a place of peace and spiritual richness, with well-preserved archaeological sites and informative displays in the museum. While some find the surrounding village commercialized, the temple complex itself is generally well-regarded for its historical and religious importance.
Positive Aspects:
Spiritual Significance:
Sarnath is where Gautama Buddha delivered his first sermon, marking the beginning of the Buddhist Sangha.
Historical Importance:
The site features ruins and structures from ancient Buddhist civilizations, including the Dhamek Stupa and the Ashoka Pillar.
Well-Maintained:
Many reviews praise the cleanliness and upkeep of the site, including the gardens and archaeological areas.
Museum:
The Sarnath Museum houses a collection of artifacts, including the Lion Capital of Ashoka, which is the national emblem of India.
Peaceful Atmosphere:
Many visitors find the site to be a peaceful and meditative place.
Informative Guides:
Guides are available to provide insights into the history and significance of the site.
Beautiful Architecture:
The Tibetan Temple in Sarnath is noted for its beautiful architecture and serene environment.
Potential Drawbacks:
Commercialization: Some reviews mention the commercialized nature of the village surrounding the temple complex.
Poor Roads: A few reviews mention the poor condition of the roads leading to Sarnath.
Heat: During midday, the heat can be intense, so it's recommended to visit in the morning or late afternoon.
Museum Restrictions: The museum requires visitors to check bags and mobile phones before entry.
Overall:
Sarnath is a must-visit for those interested in Buddhism, history, and archaeology. Despite some minor drawbacks, the site offers a unique and enriching experience, with its historical significance, well-maintained grounds, and peaceful atmosphere.

Peaceful Historical Site ‚Äì Well Maintained
Chaukhandi Stupa is a serene and historically significant place in Sarnath, where Lord Buddha is believed to have met his first disciples. The site is calm and surrounded by greenery, making it ideal for peaceful walks and reflection.

Since it is an Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) protected site, visitors are required to book entry tickets online. The fee is Rs. 20 per adult for Indian citizens, which is reasonable considering the site's importance and maintenance.

The stupa itself is well-preserved and offers a glimpse into ancient Buddhist architecture. A must-visit if you're exploring Sarnath or interested in history and spirituality.

reviews.reviewText:
I visited Darbhanga Ghat in Varanasi, and it is truly one of the most beautiful and majestic ghats in the city. What makes it stand out is the stunning architecture of the old Darbhanga Palace (now part of the BrijRama Palace hotel) that rises right beside the ghat. The grand structure, with its royal design and intricate stonework, gives the ghat a regal charm and makes it one of the most photogenic spots along the Ganga.

The ghat itself is peaceful compared to some of the busier ones, which makes it a perfect place to sit quietly, watch the river flow, and soak in the spiritual atmosphere. In the morning, the view of the sunrise from Darbhanga Ghat is absolutely mesmerizing, while in the evening you can witness the beautiful Ganga aarti at the nearby Dashashwamedh Ghat.

It‚Äôs also a great spot for photography, boating, and simply enjoying the heritage and culture of Varanasi. Walking along the steps and seeing the grand palace up close feels like stepping back in time.

Overall, Darbhanga Ghat is a must-visit if you want to experience a mix of history, architecture, and serenity in Varanasi.* üåÖüè∞‚ú®

Lovely ghat which is maintained pretty nice because of the 5-start hotel Brijrama situated at this ghat. It‚Äôs an old fort converted to a hotel now.

It‚Äôs a relatively Quieter ghat and quite picturesque as well.

You can go to the viewing spots which is at a relatively higher place and get some amazing views and shots.

People come over here and play guitar and music and chillax.

Especially at night this ghat spot is very quiet. So if you want some me time, this is the place you need to be at.

This place is very beautiful.. old style palace buildings and river is unforgettable.
with its timeless beauty, left a lasting impression on me. The old-style palace buildings, standing tall along the riverbanks, evoke a sense of history and grandeur. The serene flow of the Ganges River, coupled with the vibrant ghats bustling with life, creates a magical atmosphere that‚Äôs unforgettable. The intricate architecture and sacred rituals blend harmoniously, offering a glimpse into the soul of India. My Varanasi trip was a journey through time, culture, and spirituality, etched in memory forever.

My visit to Darbhanga Ghat in Varanasi was a truly peaceful and memorable experience. I went there seeking a sense of calm, and I found it by taking a holy Ganga snan (bath) at the ghat. The early morning dip in the river, surrounded by the serene atmosphere, was refreshing and spiritually uplifting. The view of the ancient city along the banks was stunning, and it felt like a step back in time.

After the Ganga snan, I visited the famous Kaashi Vishwanath Temple, which is a must-see for anyone visiting Varanasi. The temple's spirituality, combined with the lively surroundings, made it a unique experience. In the evening, I was fortunate to witness the mesmerizing Ganga Aarti‚Äîa captivating ceremony filled with chants, lights, and devotion. It‚Äôs an experience that truly captures the spirit of Varanasi.

The fun continued into the night as I explored the streets with friends, enjoying the vibrant night vibes of the city. Varanasi's street food is delicious, and I tried a variety of local delicacies, each bursting with flavor. The bustling lanes, with their night-time energy, were full of charm and excitement.

Overall, Darbhanga Ghat and the surrounding areas offer a perfect blend of peace, spirituality, and fun, making it an unforgettable visit for anyone looking to experience the essence of Varanasi.

Very near to the famous Dashashwamedh ghat of Banaras. A religious place with a holy significance.

Darbhanga Ghat, a serene oasis along the sacred Ganges, offers moments of tranquility and relaxation amidst the bustling energy of Varanasi. For a truly serene experience, I recommend visiting between 3-5 pm in the afternoon and after 11 pm in the evening.

During these hours, the ghat exudes a peaceful ambiance, allowing visitors to unwind and rejuvenate their minds. Simply sitting by the ghat, observing the ebb and flow of life along the river, can be a deeply calming experience.

Whether it's the gentle lapping of the water against the steps or the soft murmurs of conversations echoing in the distance, Darbhanga Ghat offers a respite from the hustle and bustle of the city. Take a moment to breathe, to observe, and to let your mind relax in the soothing embrace of this tranquil haven.

placeMetadata.name: Varuna

sources.snippet: Local lore has it that the British were terrified of the Kashi Brahmins, so they built the palace far from the notorious locals but close to Varuna‚Äîthe river that gives the city its name‚Äîwhere they constructed a small jetty and used it to collect taxes from traders passing by. It was eventually acquired by the Maharaja of Banaras, Ishwari Narain Singh Ji in 1889, who converted it to a royal guest house. A good 120 years later, the family leased it to the Taj group, that now runs it as a luxury property.

placeMetadata.name: Observatory, Man mandir

sources.snippet: In 15 th century, Sawai Man Singh of Amber built a magnificent palace named Man Singh Palace. In 19 th century, a Hindu observatory was built by Sawai Jai Singh. He was well versed in mathematics and astronomy.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Places To Visit In Varanasi And Arounds

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: A trip to Man Mandir Ghat is not complete without a visit to the Man Mandir Observatory, also known as the Jantar Mantar of Varanasi. This observatory was constructed under the guidance of Maharaja Jai Singh, who had a strong interest in science. The design and structure of this observatory bear resemblance to other observatories with the same name across India.
placeMetadata.address: Bangali Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

placeMetadata.name: Rana Mahal Ghat

sources.snippet: The exquisite Ghat constructed by the esteemed Raja Rana Jagat Singh, who embarked on a sacred pilgrimage to Varanasi. Adjacent to this serene spot, a magnificent palace stands as a testament to the Maharaja's stay during his spiritual journey. Embracing the opulent Rajputana architecture, this regal abode has become a charming attraction for numerous visitors and travelers alike.
sources.shortName: 33 Best Places to Visit in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Rana Mahal Ghat, located at the southern end of Dashaswamedh Ghat, is a picturesque spot with grand palaces showcasing Rajputana architecture. Built in 1970 by Raja Rana Jagat Singh of Udaipur, this serene area also features a magnificent palace where the Maharaja stayed during his spiritual journey. The ghat offers a tranquil and less crowded atmosphere, making it perfect for enjoying peaceful mornings and breathtaking sunrises.
placeMetadata.address: D21/20, D21/20, Bangali Tola Rd, Opp. India Company,Near Kautilya Society,Munshi Ghat, Dashaswmedh,Near baba Guest House & Shiva Guest House, Bangali Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

reviews.reviewText: Being located at the southern side of Dashaswamedh Ghat, this ghat was built in late 17th century by the king Rana Jagatsingh of Udaipur, Rajasthan. So, the ghat is called as Rana Mahal Ghat. There is a majestic palace on the ghat which shows the best of Rajputana style architecture.

The following pictures are real location pictures of the Ranamahal ghat. Many seem to have posted some other pictures on the review page for the sake of attraction which isn't the actual pictures.

Having said that, the ghat is beautiful, clean and peaceful. Visit at night or early morning for best experienceüëç

Har har mahadevüî± üôè
A really nice place to just be at. Usually very peaceful during midnight. People just sit there and chill. Also, some or the other group of people will always be performing at this place.

I totally fallen in love with this ghat. Very less crowded and deshashwmedh is walkable from here. Its so calm and peaceful over here. Sundays can be so much fun here. People will be playing swimming and full of happy faces on mornings. And the mindblowing sunrises which is a great factor to add. And the view from hotel balconies are mindblowing. There is two small tea shops in this ghats which is an added attraction for the tea lovers. Tea and ghats!! Mindblowing.

This hotel is not finished‚Ä¶ they tell you rooms are fully renovated (which it‚Äôs true) but they are not completely done. No air conditioning in rooms and no dining in premises, even though, their web page say otherwise. The bathroom in my room was still under restoration. Beware. Besides that, the hotel is beautiful and I‚Äôm sure when it‚Äôs done it would be a great boutique hotel.

This Ghat is flanked by a palace built by king Rana Jagatsingh of Udaipur, hence called as Rana Mahal ghat. There is temple dedicated to Vakratunda Vinayaka.

The place is not well kept. It is less crowded. Boat rides are available from here, but it can be a hassle to bargain with them.

The ghat has a palace built by the king Rana Jagatsingh of Udaipur and thus it is called as Rana Mahal ghat. In its vicinity at the upper part there is a shrine of Vakratunda Vinayaka.

It is very calm, less crowded and peaceful here.

In the year 1670, the Maharana of Udaipur built the Rana Mahal Ghat at the bank of the River Ganga. Approximately eighty six ghats encompass the river bank at Benaras but the sheer architecture and grandeur of Rana Mahal sets it apart from the others. The ornate Rajputi architecture is a reminder of Rana Jagat Singh of Udaipur‚Äôs great vision and foresight. Today, however, what was once a Mahal are a row of hotels. Visitors from all over the world come to the Ghat as its sheer proximity to the Dasaswamedh Ghat, where the Maha Aarti takes place, makes it a convenient pitstop. As tourists flock in to lodge here and children learn to swim, the peace and charm of the majestic Mahal is lost.

placeMetadata.name: Varanasi boat tour

sources.snippet: Rowing boat rides during the dawn is perhaps one of the best things to do in Varanasi. The ride along Ganges River offers the quintessential Varanasi experience. It takes one through different Ghats and former palaces situated close to the banks of Ganges, giving a panoramic view of this River and the region.
sources.shortName: Things to Do in Varanasi 2024: Upto 40% Off

placeMetadata.address: 72X4+HXG, Kedar ghat, Bangali Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

reviews.reviewText: A boat ride in Varanasi is a must-do experience, offering a unique perspective of the city‚Äôs iconic ghats and temples. Whether at sunrise or during the evening Ganga Aarti, the ride is both serene and captivating. Watching the city‚Äôs spiritual life unfold along the river, with priests performing rituals and devotees taking holy dips, is truly mesmerizing. Opt for a sunrise ride for peace and beauty or an evening ride to witness the magical Aarti. An unforgettable way to experience the soul of Varanasi
Its great if you are not boating in the late  evening or afteenoon

We had negotiated the itinerary, duration and price the day before with a guy who proved to be serious and precise.
The service we requested was a personal boat that reached the north of Varanasi to visit the Mosque (externally) and then resumed the descent to Assi ghat, all in the presence of a companion/guide as well as the pilot of the boat.
The total duration of the trip was 1 hour and 10 minutes as agreed. Departure at dawn, around 5 more or less depending on the season. Cost for 2 people of around 3000/3500Rp according to the agreements. Reliable. Recommended.‚úåÔ∏è

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: VaranasiWalks offers professional walking tours in Varanasi, providing visitors with in-depth knowledge and a genuine experience of the city's history, culture, and spirituality. The guides are highly knowledgeable and passionate about Varanasi, ensuring an exceptional and authentic tour through the alleys and ghats. The tours cover various significant sites including temples not easily found on one's own.
placeMetadata.address: 1/229, Assi Ghat, Next to Tiwari Lodge, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221005, India

reviews.reviewText: I am very much thankful to Mr. Jeremy Oltmann for experiencing me Varanasi with his eyes. The special early morning pooja-aarti, havan at Assi Ghat and taking part in it gives me a wonderful privilege through him. And the amazing sunrise experience riding a boat trip on ganga ji and his narrating about Varanasi taking me to visualise the purpose of the rest of my life. This spiritual journey is a wonderful memory for me. God bless you. Yes, Jeremy, I can say now, I find "peace" in Varanasi. üôèüôèüôè

Varanasi, the spiritual heart of India, pulsates with life, color, and spirituality. We embarked on an unforgettable journey through the labyrinthine alleys and ghats of Varanasi, guided by the knowledgeable and passionate Jeremy at Varanasi Walking Tours.

From the moment we met our guide, it was evident that this experience would be exceptional. His deep understanding of Varanasi's history, culture, and religious significance infused every step of our tour with richness and authenticity. As we weaved through the narrow streets, bustling markets, and ancient temples, Jeremy painted vivid pictures of the city's past and present, offering insights that I could never have gleaned on our own.

Standing on the banks, witnessing the rituals of life and death unfolding before our eyes, we were filled with a profound sense of awe and reverence. Jeremy provided invaluable context, explaining the significance of each ritual and the role of the Ganges in Hindu mythology.

But the tour was not just about sightseeing; it was a multi-sensory experience that engaged all aspects of my being. From the tantalizing aromas wafting from street food stalls to the melodious strains of devotional music echoing through the alleys, every moment was a feast for the senses.

What truly set this tour apart, however, was the genuine connections forged along the way. Whether chatting with local artisans or sharing a conversation with residents in a neighborhood we felt welcomed into the fabric of Varanasi's community. These encounters offered a glimpse into the daily lives of its inhabitants and left us with a deeper appreciation for the city's vibrant culture.

Prepare to be enchanted, enlightened, and forever changed by the magic of Varanasi with Varanasi Walking Tours!

We cannot recommend Laotse Tripathi at Varanasi Walks enough. He was so thoughtful and brought the city alive. You could tell that the beauty and wonder is in his heart and he was a wealth of knowledge about the area. He has such a knack on how to be a fantastic guide. I would highly recommend this tour agency and we are already thinking of our next trip to Varanasi and planning on booking more tours then.
We had a mourning boat tour with Laotsi and what incredible was it! Laotsi is ver gentle, explained interesting facts and answered to all of our questions. The day will be always remembered!

I had the pleasure to do 3 amazing walks with Varanasi Walks. Jeremy took me to the highlights as well as to hidden gems. With his knowledge I received an insight on Varanasi, the history and daily devotion continuesly going on in Varanasi. The respect he shows to everyone in the street made me feel very much at ease. It was a very intens, unique experience.

Jai is an extremely knowledgeable guide and made us discover the piligrim lanes of Varanasi. He made us see the beauty of the city through his eyes. We would definitely recommend his tours as you get deep insights into the history, people, culture, and religion that shape the city. Thanks Jai üôè

We did the hatha yoga walk through the city with Jay! It was absolutely amazing, he has a very unique way of conveying information and it was so interesting to get an external perspective from some who had studied yoga, learnt Sanskrit, and lived in India for 25+ years. One of the most enlightening experiences I have ever had. Would recommend this type of activity as an essential on every holiday, but since they‚Äôre only in Varanasi, you should definitely take advantage of it when you‚Äôre here!

From initial contact with the head office, who were very responsive and helpful, to the experience on the day - I cannot recommend this company enough!!

Our guide, Puppa, was knowledgeable, friendly, flexible and safety conscious. We did the hidden alleyways tour, and there were so many secret gems that we never could've found ourselves. Puppa was very passionate and attentive to the needs of my dad, who has difficultly walking longer distances.

He went the extra mile and escorted is to Assi Ghat at the end of the tour. A big big thankyou to Puppa!!

placeMetadata.name: East India Pharmaceuticals Works Limited

sources.snippet: Built between 1782 and 1788 by the East India Company, Nadesar Palace was originally made for the Tax Commissioner of Varanasi. Local lore has it that the British were terrified of the Kashi Brahmins, so they built the palace far from the notorious locals but close to Varuna‚Äîthe river that gives the city its name‚Äîwhere they constructed a small jetty and used it to collect taxes from traders passing by. It was eventually acquired by the Maharaja of Banaras, Ishwari Narain Singh Ji in 1889, who converted it to a royal guest house.
sources.shortName: Look Beyond The Ghats And Explore The Royal Side Of Varanasi

ops.insert: Sarnath is a town northeast of Varanasi, in Uttar Pradesh, India. As the Lalitavistara sutra states, the Gautama Buddha chose "Deer Park by the Hill of the Fallen Sages, outside of Varanasi" for his first teaching after he attained enlightenment in Bodh Gaya. The teaching is entitled Dhammacakkappavattana sutra. Wikipedia.
Circular stone 43m-tall Buddhist shrine with bird & script carvings, dating back to 500 CE.
Large-windowed hotel restaurant serving a contemporary Indian menu in sophisticated surrounds.
This historical Buddhist stupa features a sizable mound with a brick base & octagonal tower.
Imposing sandstone palace with towering Greek pillars & turrets, with a Shiva temple & a hotel.

placeMetadata.name: Assi ghat

sources.snippet: At a distance of 3 km from Dasashwamedh Ghat and 8 km from Varanasi Junction, Assi Ghat is one of the famous ghats on the banks of River Ganga in Varanasi. Situated at the confluence of Ganga and Assi Rivers, it is the southernmost ghat in Kashi and also one of the important Places to visit in Varanasi.Assi Ghat has numerous references in the early literature of the Hindus including Agni Purana, Matsya Purana, Padma Purana, Kurma Purana and Kashi Khand. According to the mythology, Goddess Durga had thrown her sword in Assi River after killing the demons Shumbha & Nishumbha.

placeMetadata.name: Sarnath

sources.snippet: At a distance of 10 km from Varanasi, 135 km from Allahabad, 163 km from Aurangabad, 191 km from Gorakhpur, 233 km from Rewa, 244 km from Patna, 248 km from Gaya, 306 km from Lucknow, and 338 km from Kanpur, Sarnath is a revered Buddhist pilgrimage center located in the Varanasi district of Uttar Pradesh. Situated at the confluence of Ganga and Varuna Rivers, it is one of the sacred Buddhist pilgrimage sites in India and also one of the must include places in Varanasi Tour Packages.Also known as Ishipatna, and Mrigadaya, Sarnath is one of the four most important Buddhist pilgrimage centers of India, the other three being Lumbini, Bodh Gaya, and Kushinagar. According to the legend, Lord Buddha after attaining enlightenment at Bodh Gaya came to Sarnath and delivered his first sermon to his five disciples.

sources.snippet: There are few destinations in India without a fort, and Varanasi is no exception. About 14 kilometers from the city center, you'll find Ramnagar Fort. The 18th-century sandstone fort and palace is no longer used as a defensive structure but instead houses a quirky museum brimming with vintage automobiles, elaborate hookahs, antique weapons, sedan chairs decked out in jewels, and a one-of-a-kind astronomical clock that's more than 150 years old.

reviews.reviewText:
My visit to Dashashwamedh Ghat in Varanasi was nothing short of magical. This is the heart of spiritual India, especially during the famous Ganga Aarti that takes place every evening. The atmosphere is electric ‚Äî chants, bells, and the sight of hundreds of lamps illuminating the river create an experience that words can hardly capture.

However, it's important to plan ahead! The ghat gets extremely crowded, with devotees and tourists filling every inch of space. I would highly recommend reaching by 4 PM if you want a front-level seat. After that, it becomes almost impossible to even find a place to stand. Despite the rush, witnessing the Ganga Aarti up close is absolutely worth every bit of effort.

The energy, the devotion, and the stunning views of the Ganges under the evening sky make it an unforgettable memory. If you truly want to feel the soul of Varanasi, Dashashwamedh Ghat is the place to be.

This is the main ghat of Varanasi and definitely the busiest spot along the Ganges. It‚Äôs absolutely bustling with activity throughout the day. Early mornings bring crowds of people gathering to watch the beautiful sunrise over the river, while evenings are packed with visitors coming to witness the mesmerizing aarti puja ceremony. The energy here is incredible. you‚Äôll find locals and tourists alike all mixed together, creating this wonderful, chaotic atmosphere that feels so authentically Varanasi

Dashashwamedh Ghat is undoubtedly one of the most iconic and spiritually significant places in Varanasi. Set along the banks of the sacred Ganga, the ghat offers a deeply peaceful experience‚Äîespecially during the early mornings or late nights when the crowds are thinner. The calmness of the river, the chanting of mantras in the background, and the occasional ring of temple bells together create a truly serene atmosphere that is difficult to put into words.

One of the main highlights here is the Ganga Aarti, which takes place every evening around sunset. It‚Äôs a grand, mesmerizing ritual performed by priests with synchronized movements, conch shells, and flaming lamps. The entire event is visually stunning and spiritually moving. However, it does get extremely crowded during the Aarti, so it‚Äôs a good idea to arrive early if you want a decent spot to watch. Alternatively, watching it from a boat offers a less congested and equally beautiful perspective.

Speaking of boats, rides are easily available and highly recommended‚Äîespecially during sunrise or sunset. A boat ride along the ghats allows you to witness the full stretch of Varanasi‚Äôs sacred riverfront, dotted with temples, historic structures, and daily life unfolding in its rawest form. It‚Äôs a peaceful, reflective experience that complements the energy of the ghat itself.

Another positive point is the cleanliness. Compared to some other ghats, Dashashwamedh is relatively well-maintained, especially considering the huge number of visitors it attracts daily. Authorities and volunteers seem to make a good effort to keep the place tidy, though peak hours do bring some inevitable crowd-related littering.

In summary, Dashashwamedh Ghat is a must-visit if you're in Varanasi‚Äînot just for its religious significance, but for the unique energy it offers. Whether you're a spiritual seeker, a culture lover, or simply someone looking to experience the soul of the city, this ghat captures it all. Just be prepared for crowds during popular times and plan accordingly for the best experience.

The best place to experience rich, old, and diverse cultures of India.
Will not explain the mythological history of this place as the Internet is already flooded with the same.
Experience the Ganga Ji Arti from this ghat or just sit and relax during the late nights or early mornings. The place has magic that keeps you attached and attracted.

Nestled along the sacred banks of the River Ganges in the ancient city of Varanasi, Dasaswamedh Ghat is a spiritual epicenter that captivates the soul. For anyone traveling to India to explore its spiritual heartland, this ghat stands as an essential experience. I visited Varanasi with the hope of connecting with India‚Äôs deep cultural and religious roots, and what I witnessed at Dasaswamedh Ghat exceeded my expectations in every sense. From dawn till dusk, it is a vibrant confluence of life, spirituality, chaos, and tranquility. But it‚Äôs the Ganga Aarti at dusk that seals this place in your memory forever.

‚∏ª

First Impressions: The Ghat‚Äôs Timeless Aura

As I stepped onto Dasaswamedh Ghat for the first time, I was immediately struck by the overwhelming energy of the place. The name Dasaswamedh translates to ‚Äúthe place of ten sacrificed horses,‚Äù believed to be where Lord Brahma performed the ten-horse sacrifice to welcome Lord Shiva. The mythological significance is deeply rooted in the very stones of this ghat, and you can feel that sacred aura in the air.

The ghat is a wide stretch of steps that descend to the river, flanked by temples and bustling with pilgrims, locals, sadhus, hawkers, and tourists. Early mornings reveal yogis meditating, locals taking ritual baths, and priests performing pujas (prayers) ‚Äî all creating a living, breathing rhythm of devotion. The sound of temple bells and chanting mantras adds to the ethereal charm.

‚∏ª

River Ganges: Sacred, Alive, and All-Embracing

The Ganges is more than just a river ‚Äî she is ‚ÄúMaa Ganga‚Äù, a living goddess for millions. Watching people bathe in her waters, immersing themselves in prayers or scattering ashes of loved ones, I couldn‚Äôt help but reflect on the significance of this river in Indian spirituality. I took a morning boat ride from Assi Ghat to Dasaswamedh, and seeing the sun rise over the ghats, turning the river golden, was a moment of surreal beauty.

Boatmen share stories, legends, and snippets of local wisdom, and even if you don‚Äôt speak Hindi, the emotion and reverence they express toward the river are palpable. For a tourist, it is humbling ‚Äî the sheer scale of human faith on display is unlike anything I‚Äôve ever witnessed.

‚∏ª

Ganga Aarti: A Theatrical Devotion to the Divine

Every evening, just after sunset, Dasaswamedh Ghat transforms into an open-air temple of cosmic proportions. The Ganga Aarti, performed by a group of young priests (pandits), is a coordinated ritual of light, sound, and devotion that feels more like a spiritual performance than a religious ceremony.

We arrived around 5:30 PM to secure a good spot ‚Äî I recommend getting there early, as crowds swell quickly. You can either find a place on the steps or, better yet, hire a boat and watch the ceremony from the river itself, which provides a majestic front-row view.

As darkness begins to fall, the priests dressed in traditional saffron and gold robes arrive with incense sticks, conch shells, and large multi-tiered oil lamps. The Aarti begins with the chanting of Vedic hymns and the blowing of conch shells. Then, in a perfectly synchronized flow, the priests begin their rituals ‚Äî rotating the lamps in elaborate circular motions, creating patterns of light and smoke that rise toward the heavens.

The atmosphere becomes electric. Hundreds of spectators chant ‚ÄúHar Har Gange,‚Äù while others simply close their eyes, lost in prayer or awe. The scent of sandalwood, camphor, and burning ghee fills the air. The Ganga, meanwhile, glows with hundreds of diyas (oil lamps) floating in small leaf boats offered by the devotees.

No video or photograph can do justice to the energy and reverence of this moment. It‚Äôs one of the rare experiences where religious ritual becomes a multisensory spectacle, enveloping you in spirituality regardless of your own beliefs. Even as a foreigner or outsider to the Hindu tradition, I felt moved and strangely at peace.

The entire Varanasi ghats along river Ganga is too divine with  extremely spiritual experience.
All the ghats across Ganga have their own attractions  providing soothing, peaceful and fulfilling expert.Dashashwamedh ghat is the most prominent and brimming with devotees A boat ride along the  river Ganga is not to be missed , watching the myriad facts of life and death , including the cremation at Manikarnika ghat.
Varanasi's spiritual charm is unmatched.

Review of Dashashwamedh Ghat

Dashashwamedh Ghat, located on the banks of the sacred Ganges River in Varanasi, is one of the most vibrant and spiritually significant ghats in India. Steeped in mythology, it is believed that Lord Brahma performed ten Ashwamedha Yajnas here, giving the ghat its name. It stands as a focal point for both devotees and tourists alike.

The ghat comes alive at dawn with pilgrims taking holy dips, and reaches its spiritual peak in the evening during the famous Ganga Aarti. The synchronized chanting of mantras, rhythmic beating of drums, and the sight of priests performing rituals with large brass lamps create a divine ambiance that leaves every visitor mesmerized. Watching hundreds of floating diyas (lamps) on the river during Aarti is truly a soul-stirring experience.

The surroundings are bustling with local vendors, flower sellers, and spiritual seekers. Boat rides at sunrise offer a panoramic view of the ghats and temples lining the riverbank. Despite the crowds, the energy here is deeply calming and devotional.

In essence, Dashashwamedh Ghat is not just a tourist attraction but a timeless symbol of India‚Äôs spiritual heritage, offering a unique blend of faith, tradition, and visual grandeur that lingers in the heart long after a visit.

Dashashwamedh Ghat ‚Äì The Heartbeat of Varanasi

Dashashwamedh Ghat is undoubtedly one of the most vibrant and iconic ghats in Varanasi, pulsating with life and spirituality. Situated along the sacred Ganges River, this ghat is not only a bustling hub for pilgrims but also a cultural centerpiece where ancient traditions come alive every day.

One of the most captivating experiences here is the evening Ganga Aarti, a mesmerizing ritual where priests perform synchronized prayers with lamps, accompanied by chants and devotional music. The sight of flickering flames reflecting on the river‚Äôs surface, combined with the rhythmic sounds of conch shells and bells, creates an atmosphere charged with devotion and awe. This ceremony draws huge crowds, including locals and tourists, all united in reverence and wonder.

During the day, Dashashwamedh Ghat is a hive of activity ‚Äî boats ferry visitors for river rides, vendors sell flowers and souvenirs, and sadhus (holy men) offer blessings. The steps leading down to the water are perfect for people-watching and soaking in the spiritual energy of the city.

Visiting Dashashwamedh Ghat is a must for anyone seeking to experience the true essence of Varanasi ‚Äî a blend of faith, tradition, and vibrant daily life, set against the timeless backdrop of the Ganges. It‚Äôs an unforgettable glimpse into India‚Äôs soul.

reviews.reviewText:
Bharat Kala Bhavan, located within the prestigious Banaras Hindu University (BHU) campus in Varanasi, is a treasure trove of art, culture, and history. Established in 1920, this museum is one of the finest in India, showcasing a remarkable collection of artifacts, paintings, sculptures, textiles, and historical objects that reflect India‚Äôs rich cultural heritage.

The museum is divided into several galleries, each dedicated to a specific theme or era. The **Indian Miniature Paintings Gallery** is a standout, featuring exquisite works from the Mughal, Rajput, and Pahari schools. The **Sculpture Gallery** houses ancient and medieval sculptures, including rare pieces from the Gupta and Kushan periods. The **Textile Gallery** displays a stunning array of traditional Indian fabrics, including Banarasi silk, which Varanasi is famous for.

One of the highlights of Bharat Kala Bhavan is the **Nicholas Roerich Gallery**, which showcases the works of the renowned Russian artist who was deeply influenced by Indian culture and spirituality. The museum also has a fascinating collection of historical artifacts, including coins, manuscripts, and decorative arts.

The museum is well-maintained, with informative plaques and descriptions accompanying each exhibit. The staff is knowledgeable and eager to assist visitors, making the experience even more enriching. The serene environment of the BHU campus adds to the charm of the visit.

Bharat Kala Bhavan is a must-visit for art lovers, history buffs, and anyone interested in exploring India‚Äôs cultural legacy. The entry fee is nominal, and the museum is easily accessible within the BHU campus.

The display of miniature paintings, terracotta art, and Buddhist artifacts stood out the most. The staff was polite and helpful, guiding us to explore different galleries Kala Bhawan is not just a museum but a treasure house of knowledge and creativity. It is a must-visit for students, researchers, and anyone interested in Indian art and history. The experience was inspiring and left me with a deeper appreciation of our cultural roots.

A very peaceful place . Bharat Kala Bhawan is truly one of the gems inside Banaras Hindu University. It is not just a museum but a journey through India‚Äôs history, culture, and art. The collection is vast and diverse ‚Äî from ancient sculptures, coins, and terracotta pieces to exquisite miniature paintings and textiles. What I loved the most was how beautifully the museum preserves the essence of India‚Äôs heritage in one place.

The galleries are well-organized, and each section has detailed information that makes it easier to understand the historical importance of the artifacts. The miniature painting section, in particular, is mesmerizing ‚Äî it feels like stepping back into the Mughal and Rajput eras.

Another special aspect is the connection of Bharat Kala Bhawan with Banaras itself. Many exhibits reflect the cultural richness of Varanasi, its traditions, and its role as a living museum of Indian heritage.

Overall, my visit was enriching and peaceful. It‚Äôs a must-visit for students, researchers, or anyone interested in art and history. The museum is not too crowded, which makes it easy to explore at your own pace.

‚≠ê Rating: 4.5/5 ‚Äî A beautiful treasure house of Indian culture worth visiting at least once!

Bharat Kala Bhavan, a renowned university museum located within the Banaras Hindu University in Varanasi, stands as a testament to India's rich artistic and cultural heritage. This Important museum has played a pivotal role in Sharing information about Indian art and culture.
A significant tourist attraction within the university and the city itself, Bharat Kala Bhavan Has a wonderful collection from many different time periods. It opens at 10.30 am with 20 Rs ticket for the visitors. Visitors can explore a diverse array of artifacts, including:
‚Ä¢ Sculptures: Buddhist and Hindu sculptures dating back to the 1st-15th centuries.
‚Ä¢ Paintings: Mughal miniatures, paintings from various schools, and a rare collection of Gujarati, Rajasthani, and Pahari miniature paintings.
‚Ä¢ Textiles: Exquisite brocade textiles and a wide range of costumes.
‚Ä¢ Decorative Arts: Pottery, metal crafts, ivory goods, jewelry, and terracotta beads.
Beyond these, the museum houses a wealth of archival materials, archaeological artifacts, decorative art objects, Indian philately, literary works, and personalia collections. With a total of 104,376 items in its collection, Bharat Kala Bhavan offers a comprehensive and captivating exploration of India's artistic and cultural legacy.
The museum also houses the official Bharat Ratna award presented to Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya, the esteemed founder of Banaras Hindu University.

It is a thoughtfully designed museum that balances tradition and modernity, both in its architecture and curation. reviews.reviewText:
The Shri Kashi Vishwanath Temple is not just a sacred site ‚Äî it‚Äôs the spiritual heartbeat of Varanasi, and one of the most powerful places I‚Äôve ever visited. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, the temple radiates an aura that‚Äôs difficult to put into words but deeply felt the moment you step inside the complex.

Despite the high footfall of devotees and tight security, everything is incredibly well-organized. The temple staff and volunteers guide you with patience and respect, ensuring everyone gets their darshan peacefully. The architecture itself is a beautiful blend of tradition and majesty ‚Äî the golden spire gleams against the sky, a symbol of Varanasi‚Äôs eternal spirit.

What struck me most was the intensity of devotion. Standing in front of the Jyotirlinga, with chants of ‚ÄúHar Har Mahadev‚Äù filling the air, I felt a rare kind of stillness ‚Äî a connection with something far beyond the physical. Whether you're deeply religious or just spiritually curious, the energy inside the sanctum is palpable.

Early morning visits are especially powerful ‚Äî the aarti, the sound of bells, and the scent of sandalwood and incense create a soul-stirring atmosphere. The newly developed Kashi Vishwanath Corridor has beautifully transformed the area around the temple ‚Äî making it more spacious, accessible, and visually stunning while retaining its sacred vibe.

There are small shrines and courtyards throughout the complex that are worth exploring, each with its own story and significance. Don‚Äôt miss spending a few quiet moments at the Ganga-facing side of the corridor ‚Äî it's peaceful and offers an incredible view of the river.

This temple is not just a destination ‚Äî it‚Äôs a spiritual moment, a living tradition, and a place where the past, present, and divine converge. Visiting Kashi Vishwanath is more than a religious journey ‚Äî it‚Äôs an emotional, cultural, and soulful experience.

The temple is beautifully maintained, and the darshan was smooth despite the crowd. Walking through the vibrant streets of Kashi with family made it even more special. A must visit for anyone seeking blessings and inner calm. Truly unforgettable moments in the heart of Varanasi.

I had heard a lot about Manikarnika Ghat. You will come here and get to know the truth of life.

You will find many boats for boating here. You can worship and take a bath here. There is a temple nearby, you can visit it.

Manikarnika Ghat is one of the famous and unique ghats by the Ganga River. It is different from other ghats because it is where Hindus burn dead bodies. People believe that burning a body here helps the soul become free from being born and dying again, which they call Moksha.
Early one morning, around 4 AM in December 2024, we went to Manikarnika Ghat. It was the third time we had been to this place. We were there to join the line for the Kashi Vishwanath Temple Darshan and the path took us through Manikarnika Ghat. It was very crowded because of the Kumbh Mela in Prayagraj. As we walked, we saw many funeral pyres where bodies were being burned. We stopped for a moment to respect the people who had died. Watching the burning pyres and the priests doing their rituals made us feel sad. It was a very deep and emotional experience. The flames went up high, and there was a unique,old smell. It made us think about how short life is. But that feeling didn't last long, and we got caught up in the usual things of life again. We continued walking through the ghat to reach the temple line, leaving the burning bodies behind, even though that's the truth of life. Visiting Manikarnika Ghat was a powerful experience. Seeing the cremations made us think a lot about life and death. We got to see ancient Hindu traditions being practiced. The ghat is always busy, with funeral fires burning all day and night by the Ganga River. Lastly,the ghat‚Äôs message is that death is the ultimate truth.

Manikarnika Ghat in Varanasi is one of the most sacred cremation sites along the Ganges River, steeped in spiritual significance and vibrant rituals. Visitors can witness the profound cultural heritage and the poignant beauty of life and death interwoven in this timeless location. It's a must-visit for those seeking an authentic experience of Varanasi's rich traditions.

"Manikarnika Ghat in Varanasi is a place where one can experience the confluence of life and death.
The tradition of funeral rites that continues here seems unique.
The mysterious and solemn atmosphere at the ghat deeply touches the mind.
This place, where spirituality and reality appear together, is unforgettable."

Manikarnika Ghat, located in Varanasi (Kashi), India, is one of the most sacred and significant cremation ghats along the banks of the River Ganga..
Manikarnika Ghat in Varanasi is not just a place‚Äîit's a powerful experience. As one of the oldest and most sacred cremation ghats in India, it holds deep spiritual meaning for Hindus who believe that being cremated here grants liberation (moksha) from the cycle of rebirth.
The atmosphere is intense and humbling. Funeral pyres burn day and night, reminding visitors of the impermanence of life. Despite the sorrow surrounding death, there‚Äôs a profound sense of peace and acceptance. The rituals, the chants, and the unwavering flame of the sacred fire offer a deeply reflective and spiritual experience.
It‚Äôs not a tourist spot in the usual sense‚Äîit's a living, breathing place of faith, tradition, and raw human emotion. Visiting Manikarnika Ghat is a stark but moving encounter with the spiritual heart of India.

The main cremation ghat of Varanasi, here you'll find dead bodies burning 24x7. One must visit this place once in life to face the ultimate reality. The Ratneswar Mahadev temple is situated close to this ghat. Beware of people asking for money in the name of cremation as those are mostly scams.

Varanasi's holiest cremation ground
Perched along the banks of the river Ganga lies Manikarnika Ghat, a powerful symbol of life and death, as it serves as one of the holiest sites for cremation in Hindu tradition. It is here that you witness the eternal cycle of life and death unfold with solemn reverence.

Attending the BHU NCC camp was truly one of the best experiences of our lives. We went there for best cadet camp selection, CATC, TSC training, and firing practice, and every single day was full of excitement and learning. The firing sessions taught us discipline and focus, while the drills and physical training kept us fit and motivated. We had ground discussions that encouraged teamwork and leadership, and the environment was always filled with energy thanks to all the singing, dancing, and cultural activities in the evenings. The 28 UP Girls Battalion really felt like a second family‚Äîeveryone supported each other, and no one ever felt left out. We made so many new friends from different places, including naval cadets who joined in and shared their own stories and skills, making our experience even more diverse and fun. The camp staff and instructors were strict yet caring, always pushing us to do our best while making sure we were safe and learning the right way. The food was another highlight: five tasty meals a day including snacks, making sure we were always full of energy for the next activity. We loved sitting together in the mess hall, sharing jokes and stories. Even simple things like standing in line for meals, preparing for inspection, or late-night chats in the barracks became moments we‚Äôll never forget. Honestly, none of us wanted to go back home because the bonds we built and the memories we created here were so special. Overall, the BHU NCC camp wasn‚Äôt just about training‚Äîit was about friendship, discipline, fun, and growing into better versions of ourselves.

One of the most well maintained, beautiful and scenic Universities of India, BHU is located just 4.5KMs from the Kashi Vishwanath Temple.

The reason I made a stop here on my trip to Varanasi was to witness the exact replica of Bhagwaan Kashi Vishwanath located inside the University.

Man I must say, the temple is spectacular. Spread across an acre, The temple tower is a massive structure standing at over 50 feet from base. The temple itself is made of marble and the interior is pretty neat, well maintained.

On the first floor, you'll also find individual temples of Bhagwan Shri Satyanarayana and Bhagwan Bholenaath both of which are made of Marble.

The landscape is lush green having few benches to relax and unwind.

Bottom line, when in Varanasi, you have to visit BHU too.

Manikarnika Ghat is one of the famous and unique ghats by the Ganga River. It is different from other ghats because it is where Hindus burn dead bodies. People believe that burning a body here helps the soul become free from being born and dying again, which they call Moksha.
Early one morning, around 4 AM in December 2024, we went to Manikarnika Ghat. It was the third time we had been to this place. We were there to join the line for the Kashi Vishwanath Temple Darshan and the path took us through Manikarnika Ghat. It was very crowded because of the Kumbh Mela in Prayagraj. As we walked, we saw many funeral pyres where bodies were being burned. We stopped for a moment to respect the people who had died. Watching the burning pyres and the priests doing their rituals made us feel sad. It was a very deep and emotional experience. The flames went up high, and there was a unique,old smell. It made us think about how short life is. But that feeling didn't last long, and we got caught up in the usual things of life again. We continued walking through the ghat to reach the temple line, leaving the burning bodies behind, even though that's the truth of life. Visiting Manikarnika Ghat was a powerful experience. Seeing the cremations made us think a lot about life and death. We got to see ancient Hindu traditions being practiced. The ghat is always busy, with funeral fires burning all day and night by the Ganga River. Lastly,the ghat‚Äôs message is that death is the ultimate truth.

Manikarnika Ghat, located in Varanasi (Kashi), India, is one of the most sacred and significant cremation ghats along the banks of the River Ganga..
Manikarnika Ghat in Varanasi is not just a place‚Äîit's a powerful experience. As one of the oldest and most sacred cremation ghats in India, it holds deep spiritual meaning for Hindus who believe that being cremated here grants liberation (moksha) from the cycle of rebirth.
The atmosphere is intense and humbling. Funeral pyres burn day and night, reminding visitors of the impermanence of life. Despite the sorrow surrounding death, there‚Äôs a profound sense of peace and acceptance. The rituals, the chants, and the unwavering flame of the sacred fire offer a deeply reflective and spiritual experience.
It‚Äôs not a tourist spot in the usual sense‚Äîit's a living, breathing place of faith, tradition, and raw human emotion. Visiting Manikarnika Ghat is a stark but moving encounter with the spiritual heart of India.

"Manikarnika Ghat in Varanasi is a place where one can experience the confluence of life and death.
The tradition of funeral rites that continues here seems unique.
The mysterious and solemn atmosphere at the ghat deeply touches the mind.
This place, where spirituality and reality appear together, is unforgettable."

Varanasi's holiest cremation ground
Perched along the banks of the river Ganga lies Manikarnika Ghat, a powerful symbol of life and death, as it serves as one of the holiest sites for cremation in Hindu tradition. It is here that you witness the eternal cycle of life and death unfold with solemn reverence.

The main cremation ghat of Varanasi, here you'll find dead bodies burning 24x7. One must visit this place once in life to face the ultimate reality. The Ratneswar Mahadev temple is situated close to this ghat. Beware of people asking for money in the name of cremation as those are mostly scams.

Some ghats are backed by imposing palaces, and others, like Manikarnika Ghat, are sacred cremation sites.

reviews.reviewText:
The Nepali Temple, situated in the heart of Varanasi near Lalita Ghat, is a serene architectural marvel that blends spirituality and exquisite craftsmanship. Built by the King of Nepal in the 19th century, this temple is a hidden gem that radiates peace amidst the bustling chaos of the city. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, the temple is also referred to as the "Mini Khajuraho" because of its intricate wooden carvings, which depict celestial beings, deities, and mythological stories.

What sets the Nepali Temple apart is its unique design inspired by traditional Nepali pagoda-style architecture. Constructed primarily of wood and stone, the structure boasts an array of finely detailed sculptures that are a testament to the skill of Nepali artisans. The use of termite-resistant wood adds to its timeless charm, ensuring its longevity even in the humid climate of Varanasi.

The temple is not only a place of worship but also a peaceful retreat for those seeking solace and introspection. Overlooking the serene Ganges River, it offers breathtaking views that enhance its tranquil ambiance. The sound of temple bells, combined with the distant chants from the ghats, creates an otherworldly experience.

Visitors often find themselves mesmerized by the spiritual energy and cultural richness of the place. Whether you're an architecture enthusiast, a devotee, or simply a traveler seeking peace, the Nepali Temple is a must-visit destination that encapsulates the profound spiritual essence of Varanasi.

The Nepali Temple is a hidden gem with stunning traditional wooden architecture that stands out beautifully. It has a peaceful atmosphere and is much quieter compared to other spots in Varanasi, making it perfect for a calm visit. The intricate carvings and design reflect Nepalese culture and craftsmanship. A must-visit if you‚Äôre in the area and want to experience something different and serene.

Shri Samrajeswar Pashupatinath Mahadev Mandir, popularly known as the Nepali Mandir, is a hidden gem in the heart of Varanasi. Built in the 19th century by the King of Nepal, this temple stands out with its unique architecture, crafted from terracotta, stone, and wood. Often referred to as Mini Khajuraho, it showcases intricate wooden carvings that are truly mesmerizing.

Dedicated to Lord Shiva, the temple holds immense religious significance and offers a peaceful retreat from the bustling city. Its design replicates the iconic Pashupatinath Temple in Kathmandu, making it a must-visit for history buffs and spiritual seekers alike.

If you're in Varanasi, don't miss this beautiful blend of art, culture, and devotion!

Scindia Ghat in Varanasi is renowned for its historical and spiritual significance. Built by the Scindia dynasty in 1830, this ghat features the famous Ratneshwar Mahadev Temple, which is partially submerged in the Ganges. This "leaning temple" adds a unique charm and mystique to the location. The temple is believed to be over 150 years old and has been sinking due to the weight of the ghat's construction.

A Historical and Mystical Experience at Scindia Ghat**

Scindia Ghat in Varanasi is a fascinating place that combines historical significance with mystical charm. Here's a detailed review of my visit:

**Location and Accessibility:**
Scindia Ghat is located north of Dashashwamedh Ghat and can be reached by a short walk from there or by taking a boat ride along the Ganges. It‚Äôs easily accessible and well-connected by local transport.

**Atmosphere:**
The atmosphere at Scindia Ghat is unique and intriguing. It's less crowded than some of the more popular ghats, offering a quieter and more introspective experience. The ghat is characterized by its partially submerged Shiva temple, which adds a mystical and almost otherworldly quality to the environment. The sound of the river, combined with the sight of the sunken temple and the ancient structures, creates a captivating ambiance.

**Historical and Cultural Significance:**
Scindia Ghat is named after the Scindia (Shinde) family of Madhya Pradesh, who built it in the early 19th century. The ghat is particularly famous for the tilted Shiva temple, which sank partially during its construction. This sunken temple is a major attraction and a subject of many legends and local lore. The ghat is also linked to the birth of Agni, the god of fire, according to Hindu mythology, adding to its spiritual significance.

**Activities:**
- **Religious Practices:** The ghat is a site for various religious rituals and ceremonies. Devotees often visit the sunken temple to offer prayers.
- **Exploration:** The ancient architecture and the partially submerged temple offer great opportunities for exploration and photography. The ghat‚Äôs historical structures and the scenic views of the Ganges are truly photogenic.
- **Boat Rides:** Boat rides from Scindia Ghat provide a different perspective of the river and the ghats, especially during sunrise and sunset. The sight of the tilted temple from the boat is particularly striking.
- **Spiritual Reflection:** The quieter environment makes it an ideal spot for meditation and reflection. The mystical atmosphere adds to the spiritual experience.

**Cleanliness and Facilities:**
Scindia Ghat is relatively clean, though, like many places in Varanasi, it faces challenges due to the high foot traffic and religious activities. Efforts are made by local authorities and communities to maintain cleanliness. Basic amenities like restrooms and small eateries are available nearby.

**Safety:**
The ghat is generally safe for visitors. The area is frequented by locals and tourists alike, creating a sense of security. However, as with any crowded place, it's advisable to keep an eye on personal belongings and be cautious, especially during peak hours.

**Conclusion:**
Scindia Ghat is a must-visit for those interested in history, mythology, and the mystical aspects of Varanasi. Its unique features, such as the partially submerged Shiva temple and its serene environment, make it stand out among the many ghats of Varanasi. Whether you are a spiritual seeker, a history enthusiast, or a curious traveler, Scindia Ghat offers a rich and captivating experience.

**Pro Tips:**
1. Visit during the early morning or late afternoon to enjoy the serene atmosphere and avoid the midday heat.
2. Take a boat ride for a unique view of the ghat and the sunken temple.
3. Bring a camera to capture the mystical and historical elements of the ghat.

**Final Thoughts:**
My visit to Scindia Ghat was a highlight of my trip to Varanasi. The combination of historical intrigue, spiritual significance, and serene beauty makes it a place worth visiting. Scindia Ghat offers a glimpse into the mystical side of Varanasi, making it a memorable and enriching experience.

Scindia Ghat is distinguished from the other famous ghats in Varanasi with its partially submerged Lord Shiva temple. The story behind its submersion is an extremely fascinating one. To its north side lies the Manikarnika Ghat while the other popular ghat in Varanasi, Dashashwamedh Ghat lies at a distance of 1.2 km approx. from it. ¬†The temple which remains partially submerged in the River Ganga is known as the Ratneshwar Shiva Temple, or simply, leaning Shiva Temple. It is believed that the temple was submerged almost 150 years because it was unable to bear the weight of the ghat. People believe that it has been drowning ever since and there will come a time when it will be completely submerged. There is also a mythological tale behind the temple‚Äôs submergence.
According to the tale, a boy by the name of Man Singh had a mother who was in love with a man, and wanted to marry him. The boy disapproved of this relationship and wanted to clear whatever debt he felt he owed his mother. Once he had done this, he thought, he would cut all ties with her. The mother was unwilling to bring the relationship to an end from her side and asked him to do that instead. With that objective in mind, he arrived at Kashi and built a temple dedicated to Lord Shiva. By doing so, he felt he had paid off any debt he owed his mother. Upon visiting the temple, however, his mother was enraged and said that nothing could pay off a mother‚Äôs love towards her child. Since then, the temple was cursed and remained submerged under water. During summers though, when the waters of River Ganga subside a little, the garbagriha (sanctum sanctorum) of the temple is visible, thus becoming a special attraction for devotees.

Varanasi, often called Kashi or the ‚ÄòCity of Lights‚Äô by Hindus, is a city with deep roots. Some say its first inhabitants settled around 1000 BC. Legend has it that the city was created by the Hindu god, Lord Shiva, making it around 3000 years old. With its 87 riverfront steps, known as ghats, Varanasi is a living testament to ancient traditions.

Chet Singh Ghat, situated on the banks of the Ganges in Varanasi, is a historically significant and visually stunning location. The ghat is named after Maharaja Chet Singh, who once ruled Varanasi and fought against the British during the 18th century. The fort at the ghat adds to its historical charm, though it remains largely abandoned.

Pros:

reviews.reviewText:
Don't miss Sarnath if you are visiting Varanasi. It's a major Buddhist archaelogical site (monasteries ruins, Buddhist temple, etc.) that has now developed into a major Buddhist pilgrimage site. There's a lot to see, and if you are an archaeology or Buddhist history enthusiast and have got the time, it's worth a day of exploration. Let me summarize what you can explore here, along with some suggestions:

1) Dhamek Stupa: It's a huge ancient (5th AD) stupa as you can see in the photos, and the main attraction of Sarnath complex. Trust me, it's something, with intricate carvings and strange ancient writings (Brahmi) on its circular wall.

2) Monastery ruins: There are ancient monastery ruins which have been excavated from ground over the century (first by British, then by Indian government). I am not very familiar with the details, but there are some important artifacts and features like Ashokan pillars etc. (on the pillar ruins, there are writings in an ancient Brahmi language).

3) Buddhist Museum: Many important items that have been excavated from the site are stored in this Museum. A must-see place.

4) There are many more noteworthy places to visit nearby,. This includes a very large and beautiful Japanese temple with a sleeping Buddha, a Myanmar-style pagoda, a huge standing Buddha statue inside a Thai monastery complex, Sarnath Buddhist temple, and many more monasteries (we had to miss few due to time constraints, especially as we had seen lots and lots of monasteries in Bodh Gaya 2 years back).

5) International crowd: You will see lots of international tourists here, especially groups from South East Asia and Far East. You will even see entire groups from those Buddhist nations meditating and chanting on the lawns near the monastery ruins. Offers a great peek into Buddhist culture.

6) Neat and well-managed: The entire Sarnath complex is very neat and well-managed. You have ticket counters, online ticket option, wheelchairs, refreshment centers, shopping stalls at the entrance, and so on.

Suggestion: Get tickets online (both Museum & Dhamek Stupa) before visiting as the queue can be quite long at the ticket counter. Also photography is allowed here, so you can take your electronic items with you.

Visiting Dhamek Stupa was a peaceful and meaningful experience. The site holds deep historical and spiritual significance, as it‚Äôs believed to be where the Buddha gave his first sermon after enlightenment.
The stupa itself is massive and beautifully built, surrounded by well-maintained gardens and other ruins that give you a sense of the area‚Äôs importance in ancient times.
There‚Äôs a quiet, reflective atmosphere, and I‚Äôd recommend taking time to walk around slowly and take it all in.
If possible, visiting with a guide or reading up a bit beforehand adds a lot to the experience. Definitely worth a visit if you‚Äôre in Sarnath or nearby Varanasi.

Journey to Sarnath and experience the profound peace of Dhamek Stupa. This ancient monument marks the spot of Buddha's first teaching, dating back to Emperor Ashoka!
‚ÄãA masterpiece of Gupta-era architecture and a pivotal site in Buddhist history. The Dhamek Stupa in Sarnath is a must-visit for history buffs and spiritual seekers.Its A very calm place for roaming around to give relax to your body and mind.

Entrance is guided by app based payment and one enters an excellent premises maintained by the Archaeological Survey of India. Contemporary association is of the National Emblem and Ashoka Lion having originated at this venue. Light and Sound Show in the evening is great and links all the dots in following Lord Buddhas life.

üåü Sarnath ‚Äì Where History Whispers & Nature Breathes üåü
Just a few kilometers from the chaos of Varanasi lies Sarnath ‚Äì a calm, soul-stirring sanctuary where Lord Buddha gave his first sermon. If you‚Äôre chasing peace, wisdom, or just a break from city noise, this is your spot.
üõï Dhamek Stupa: Massive, timeless, and meditative. You can almost hear the chants in the wind.
üèõÔ∏è Sarnath Archaeological Museum: A treasure trove of ancient relics. Don‚Äôt miss the Lion Capital of Ashoka ‚Äì India‚Äôs national emblem. The museum is compact but loaded with powerful history. Perfect for curious minds and history geeks.
üåç Global Buddhist Temples: Walk through temples built by Japan, Thailand, Tibet, and more ‚Äì each one a work of art and culture.
ü¶Å Sarnath Deer Park (Zoo): Ideal for families and kids. Small, clean, and peaceful with a variety of animals including deer (of course!), peacocks, and some exotic birds. Great for a slow walk after temple visits.
üìú Mulagandha Kuti Vihar: A beautiful modern temple with stunning frescoes and a serene garden for meditation.
üí° Pro Tips:
‚úîÔ∏è Early morning or late afternoon is best for peaceful vibes & photos.
‚úîÔ∏è Entry fees are nominal ‚Äì carry some cash.
‚úîÔ∏è Avoid loud noises ‚Äì it‚Äôs a sacred zone.

‚ú® Verdict:
Sarnath isn‚Äôt just a day trip. It‚Äôs a soul trip. It teaches you that silence can be powerful, and peace can be found

A good place to visit if you are interested in the related subject. A very big museum contains so many buddha sculpture on the sand stone dated back to 6th-7th century. There is also a excavation place also where many old buildings, stupas are found.
Ticket is also too cheap 5 rupees for the museum and total 30rupees for the whole place.

It‚Äôs once in a life time experience to visit the origin of Buddhist teaching point.  The location is well organized with good information.  It‚Äôs clean and good for just sit there reading and mediation.  The security also active walking with alert when visitors acting inappropriate.

Overview

+13
Sarnath is a highly regarded Buddhist pilgrimage site and historical location, known for its serene atmosphere, well-maintained grounds, and significant Buddhist monuments like the Dhamek Stupa. Visitors often describe it as a place of peace and spiritual richness, with well-preserved archaeological sites and informative displays in the museum. While some find the surrounding village commercialized, the temple complex itself is generally well-regarded for its historical and religious importance.
Positive Aspects:
Spiritual Significance:
Sarnath is where Gautama Buddha delivered his first sermon, marking the beginning of the Buddhist Sangha.
Historical Importance:
The site features ruins and structures from ancient Buddhist civilizations, including the Dhamek Stupa and the Ashoka Pillar.
Well-Maintained:
Many reviews praise the cleanliness and upkeep of the site, including the gardens and archaeological areas.
Museum:
The Sarnath Museum houses a collection of artifacts, including the Lion Capital of Ashoka, which is the national emblem of India.
Peaceful Atmosphere:
Many visitors find the site to be a peaceful and meditative place.
Informative Guides:
Guides are available to provide insights into the history and significance of the site.
Beautiful Architecture:
The Tibetan Temple in Sarnath is noted for its beautiful architecture and serene environment.
Potential Drawbacks:
Commercialization: Some reviews mention the commercialized nature of the village surrounding the temple complex.
Poor Roads: A few reviews mention the poor condition of the roads leading to Sarnath.
Heat: During midday, the heat can be intense, so it's recommended to visit in the morning or late afternoon.
Museum Restrictions: The museum requires visitors to check bags and mobile phones before entry.
Overall:
Sarnath is a must-visit for those interested in Buddhism, history, and archaeology. Despite some minor drawbacks, the site offers a unique and enriching experience, with its historical significance, well-maintained grounds, and peaceful atmosphere.

reviews.reviewText:
During my trip to Varanasi, one experience that truly stood out was tasting the lassi near Manikarnika Ghat ‚Äî quite honestly, I have never had such delicious lassi in my life!

This tiny, bustling shop offers an incredible variety of lassis, many of them mixed with fresh fruits and unique syrups, creating flavors that are unbelievably tasty, rich, and creamy. Each sip feels like a dessert in itself ‚Äî refreshing, satisfying, and utterly addictive.

The shop is located very close to Manikarnika Ghat, but do keep in mind that space is extremely limited ‚Äî there‚Äôs barely enough room to stand properly, let alone sit comfortably. If you‚Äôre lucky, you might manage to grab a spot inside; otherwise, you‚Äôll likely find yourself standing outside, soaking in the atmosphere as you enjoy your lassi.

No matter which flavor you choose, you really can‚Äôt go wrong ‚Äî each one is better than the last and, in my opinion, far superior to the other lassis I tasted elsewhere in Varanasi. This place is truly a hidden gem and an absolute must-try for anyone visiting the city.

If you're a Lassi lover like me, you owe it to yourself to try this blue lassi shop. Trust me, you won't be disappointed!

I highly recommend this Lassi shop to anyone looking for a refreshing and delicious drink. The ambiance is unique and cozy, the staff is friendly, and the Lassi is top-notch. Whether you're in the mood for something sweet or tangy, this shop has got you covered. The Lassi is made with high-quality ingredients, and you can taste the freshness and authenticity in every sip. Situated in one of the timeless lanes of Banaras, the Blue Lassi Shop is a name that often comes up in every traveller's guide to Varanasi. With its rustic walls, scribbled messages from global tourists, and a reputation that precedes it
