placeMetadata.address: 92GG+RQ7, Sarnath, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221007, India

reviews.reviewText:
My visit to the Tibetan Temple in Varanasi was a truly calming and beautiful experience. Located near the famous Sarnath, this temple stands out not just for its unique Tibetan architecture, but also for the peaceful atmosphere that surrounds it. It‚Äôs the perfect place for anyone looking to experience Buddhist culture, history, and spirituality all in one spot.

As soon as you enter the temple grounds, you‚Äôre greeted by a sense of calm that‚Äôs rare to find in a busy city like Varanasi. The quiet ambiance, the soft chanting of prayers, and the gently spinning prayer wheels create a peaceful atmosphere that makes you want to just sit and soak in the serenity. Whether you‚Äôre religious or not, the calmness here instantly relaxes your mind.

The temple‚Äôs design is strikingly different from the traditional Indian temples. The bright colors, intricate wood carvings, and Tibetan symbols give the place a unique charm. The prayer wheels lined up outside the temple are a special feature ‚Äì spinning them while walking along the path is a simple yet meaningful ritual, believed to spread positive energy.

Inside the temple, there‚Äôs a beautiful statue of Lord Buddha, along with stunning Tibetan-style paintings and thangka art that depict scenes from Buddha‚Äôs life and teachings. The whole temple reflects the rich culture and artistry of Tibet, making it not just a religious place but also a cultural treasure.

The temple and its surrounding garden are very well-maintained. The pathways are clean, the gardens are full of greenery, and the temple itself is spotless. It‚Äôs clear that the caretakers take pride in keeping the temple welcoming for visitors.

The monks and staff at the temple are very friendly and happy to share stories about the temple‚Äôs history, its connection to Tibetan culture, and the meaning behind different symbols and rituals. Their warmth and willingness to share knowledge make the visit even more meaningful.

The Tibetan Temple in Varanasi is a hidden gem that offers a beautiful blend of culture, spirituality, and peacefulness. Whether you are visiting Sarnath, exploring Varanasi, or simply want to experience something unique, this temple is absolutely worth your time.

I would highly recommend for its beauty, tranquility, and cultural value.

This is a religious centre for Buddhists pilgrims. Location in Varanasi in sarnath area. There are a bunch of buddist monastery in this area belongs to different countries. This is one of them. Tibetan Buddhist Monastery is very miraculous place full of peace and holiness of God buddha.

The Tibetan Temple in Varanasi, located near the sacred town of Sarnath, is a beautiful and peaceful spiritual site that reflects Tibetan Buddhist culture and traditions. Built by the Tibetan community, this temple is dedicated to Lord Buddha and serves as an important place of worship as well as meditation. The temple‚Äôs architecture is striking, with traditional Tibetan designs, colorful frescoes, and vibrant prayer flags fluttering in the breeze, creating a serene and spiritual atmosphere.

Inside the temple, visitors can see a magnificent statue of Lord Buddha along with murals depicting scenes from his life and teachings. The walls are adorned with beautiful Tibetan art and thangka paintings, which make the temple visually appealing and culturally rich. Prayer wheels are also installed, and devotees and tourists alike spin them while chanting mantras, seeking peace and blessings.

The temple provides a calm and quiet environment, making it an ideal place for meditation and self-reflection away from the city‚Äôs hustle and bustle. It is well-maintained, and the peaceful energy here attracts both devotees and international visitors interested in Buddhism. Overall, the Tibetan Temple is a must-visit in Varanasi for those who wish to experience spiritual tranquility and explore Tibetan culture.

Sarnath, 12 km from Varanasi, is one of the 4 most holy place of Buddhism. It was here Buddha gave first sermons to His 5 disciples after attaining enlightenment. It‚Äôs a very beautiful temple. It was built in 1955 by His Holiness Dalai Lama XIV and maintained by Lhadhan Chotrul Monlam Chenmo Trust.

Nice display of Buddhism & Tibetan culture .
Place is well maintained . Clean , silent .
But , I don't like the Guides near to this temple , they force u to hire them & if u say NO , they start Miss behaving with u or pass hard comment.

Although well maintained by green garden , seating arrangements are also there .
No Entry fees.
No parking fees .

Hv some time in ur hand & seat alone to  feel the Vibes of the place .

A big Lord Budha idol located in the temple . And several other articals related to Budhism. .. the construction of the temple , it's artistic view , color and atmosphere can make u cool

The ambience is full of calmness and serenity. An impressive showcase of Tibetan Buddhist Culture. A sacred pilgrimage site present in Sarnath not only for Buddhists but also for those who sincerely seek peace of mind.

My wife and I stopped in Varanasi on our way to Nepal. We saw many things there, including the Kashi Vishwanath Temple, Ganga Aarti, Sarnath Stupa, etc. We also saw a Tibetan temple. It is a very nice, beautiful temple. There is also a Cambodian monastery nearby. It is a very beautiful work of art.

Tibetan Temple is one of the popular Buddhist monastery and temple located in Sarnath. A prominent and highly revered places of pilgrimage in Sarnath. The entrance of the temple is guarded and beautifully adorned with intricate carvings of two lions. Constructed in a traditional Tibetan architectural design, the temple houses a statue of Buddha in resting position. The temple is also decorated with Tibetan Buddhist paintings on the walls and ceilings.
Like most Buddhist temples, here also one can find a series of prayer wheels that release paper scrolls with chants written on them when one rotates them in the clockwise direction. We had a peaceful visit as the temple was thinly crowded, when we toured. In short, Tibetan Temple is one of the must-visit places in Sarnath as the place offers a true essence of spirituality and tranquility.
The presence of Buddhist monks and the sound of chanting and prayer bells add to the temple's sacred atmosphere. The Tibetan Temple is a reminder of the Buddhist teachings of compassion and mindfulness, making it a cherished spot for pilgrims and tourists seeking solace and spiritual insight.

It was constructed by Maharani Ahilyabai Holkar of Madhya Pradesh between 1778-1785 and is often seen as the backdrop in boating pictures from Varanasi. This ghat is a popular destination for religious bathing rituals and offers a serene atmosphere for spiritual seekers.

reviews.reviewText: Ahilyabai Ghat stands with quiet grace along the banks of the Ganges in Varanasi. It is well known for its calm atmosphere and beautiful architecture. Built by Queen Ahilyabai Holkar of Indore, the ghat is clean and less crowded compared to some others nearby. Steps lead gently down to the river, where people sit peacefully, offering prayers or enjoying the gentle breeze. The ghat is also a common place for morning rituals and holy dips. A few temples near the ghat add to its spiritual feel, and the stone structures reflect a touch of history. It feels more personal and reflective, with less noise and chaos. Boats pass by slowly, giving lovely views of the river and the surrounding ghats. It‚Äôs a place where silence speaks, and the calm waters reflect the deep devotion of those who visit.

Ahilyabai Ghat is a famous ghat (a series of steps leading down to the river) located on the banks of the River Ganges in Varanasi. It is named after the famous queen of the Maratha Empire, Ahilyabai Holkar, who was a great patron of the city and is credited with the construction of many ghats and temples in Varanasi.

Ahilyabai Ghat is a popular spot for taking a dip in the holy river and performing various religious rituals. It is also known for its beautiful architecture and intricate carvings on the steps and pillars. The ghat is particularly beautiful during the evening aarti (a Hindu religious ceremony) when hundreds of devotees gather to offer prayers to the river.

Apart from its religious significance, Ahilyabai Ghat is also a popular tourist destination and attracts visitors from all over the world. It is a great place to witness the unique culture and traditions of Varanasi and experience the spiritual and mystical ambiance of the city.

This ghat is next to Dashashamedh Ghat and is not very crowded. One can avail boat rides from this Ghat. Quite neat and clean. Only problem is the steep steps. One with knee issues will find it a bit difficult. But there's no other way out.

Ahilyabai Ghat located on the banks of the famous Holy river Ganga is one of the 84 ghats along the river. It is very next to the famous Dashashwamegh ghat. Punyashlok  Ahilyabai Holkar was a great devotee of Bhagwan Shiva and she has built lots of such Ghats along many rivers in India. The previous name of this ghat was Kevalgiri ghat but to pay tribute to this great Shiva Bhakta this ghat was renamed as Ahilyabai ghat. Many Hindu religious rituals can be performed here. The boat ride can also be taken from here. Do visit when in Varanasi.

Ahilyabai Ghat in Varanasi is a truly mesmerizing spot that blends history, spirituality, and natural beauty. The ancient steps leading down to the river offer a glimpse into the city's rich past. While the water at the ghat can be a bit murky, there‚Äôs a unique solution that adds to the adventure: take a boat ride across the river!

Crossing the Ganges by boat not only provides a refreshing change but also offers stunning panoramic views of Varanasi's ghats and temples from the water. Once you reach the other side, you can enjoy a revitalizing bath in cleaner waters, surrounded by the serene landscape and the iconic skyline of the city.

Ahilyabai Ghat is a must-visit for anyone looking to experience the essence of Varanasi, and the boat ride adds an unforgettable twist to your journey. Just be prepared to take that extra step for a truly rewarding experience!

Right next to Dashaswamedha Ghat in Varanasi, named after the ‚ÄúQueen of Maheshwaram‚Äù, Indore. This ghat is quiet, calm and less crowded with breathtaking views and a shiva temple in the water. Also the water is clean here due to less crowded and less polluted. Also one can have boat rides from here hassle free, usually charged around 200‚Çπ per person to go into the Ganges for a round. And 1500‚Çπ if you want a private ride to the ghats of Varanasi. Also ‚Äú Pandits ‚Äú can be found here for anyone who wants to do ‚Äúkarma‚Äù for those who passed away.

The original name of this ghat is Kevalagiri Ghat. Ahilyabai Holkar, the Queen of Indore renovated this ghat. She built several architectural landmarks across India. In her honor & memory, this ghat was renamed as the Ahilyabai Ghat. The Ahilyabai Ghat compound consists of a palace & a residential district. Along with a wrestling site (akhara), there are few religious buildings and servant quarters inside the compound. The best time to visit Ahilyabai Ghat is during early morning. Devotees take a holy dip in the holy River Ganga and pray for wash away all sins.

One of the most prominent ghats of Varanasi. It's named after the Indian queen Ahalyabai Holkar. History is intricately weved in this ghat. The ambience is very peaceful here. One can spend his/her entire day by sitting on the ghat and watching the local life. The luxurious Brijrama hotel is situated just beside this ghat.

placeMetadata.name: Darbhanga Ghat

sources.snippet: Photographers, take note: Darbhanga Ghat offers the best opportunity to get amazing shots of Varanasi. The stairs leading down to the riverbank are crowned by the ultra-luxurious BrijRama Palace, an old fort that has since been converted into a heritage hotel. The property's Greek pillars and rounded balconies give the area (and your photographs) a regal backdrop.

sources.snippet: At a distance of 6 km from Varanasi Junction, Darbhanga Ghat is located to the south of Dasashwamedh Ghat in Varanasi. This ghat is one of the famous ghats in Varanasi and also one of the places to visit in Banaras. Situated between Dasashwamedh Ghat and Rana Mahal Ghat, Darbhanga Ghat was named after Darbhanga royal family.

reviews.reviewText:
I visited Darbhanga Ghat in Varanasi, and it is truly one of the most beautiful and majestic ghats in the city. What makes it stand out is the stunning architecture of the old Darbhanga Palace (now part of the BrijRama Palace hotel) that rises right beside the ghat. The grand structure, with its royal design and intricate stonework, gives the ghat a regal charm and makes it one of the most photogenic spots along the Ganga.

The ghat itself is peaceful compared to some of the busier ones, which makes it a perfect place to sit quietly, watch the river flow, and soak in the spiritual atmosphere. In the morning, the view of the sunrise from Darbhanga Ghat is absolutely mesmerizing, while in the evening you can witness the beautiful Ganga aarti at the nearby Dashashwamedh Ghat.

It‚Äôs also a great spot for photography, boating, and simply enjoying the heritage and culture of Varanasi. Walking along the steps and seeing the grand palace up close feels like stepping back in time.

Overall, Darbhanga Ghat is a must-visit if you want to experience a mix of history, architecture, and serenity in Varanasi.* üåÖüè∞‚ú®

Lovely ghat which is maintained pretty nice because of the 5-start hotel Brijrama situated at this ghat. It‚Äôs an old fort converted to a hotel now.

It‚Äôs a relatively Quieter ghat and quite picturesque as well.

You can go to the viewing spots which is at a relatively higher place and get some amazing views and shots.

People come over here and play guitar and music and chillax.

Especially at night this ghat spot is very quiet. So if you want some me time, this is the place you need to be at.

This place is very beautiful.. old style palace buildings and river is unforgettable.
with its timeless beauty, left a lasting impression on me. The old-style palace buildings, standing tall along the riverbanks, evoke a sense of history and grandeur. The serene flow of the Ganges River, coupled with the vibrant ghats bustling with life, creates a magical atmosphere that‚Äôs unforgettable. The intricate architecture and sacred rituals blend harmoniously, offering a glimpse into the soul of India. My Varanasi trip was a journey through time, culture, and spirituality, etched in memory forever.

My visit to Darbhanga Ghat in Varanasi was a truly peaceful and memorable experience. I went there seeking a sense of calm, and I found it by taking a holy Ganga snan (bath) at the ghat. The early morning dip in the river, surrounded by the serene atmosphere, was refreshing and spiritually uplifting. The view of the ancient city along the banks was stunning, and it felt like a step back in time.

After the Ganga snan, I visited the famous Kaashi Vishwanath Temple, which is a must-see for anyone visiting Varanasi. The temple's spirituality, combined with the lively surroundings, made it a unique experience. In the evening, I was fortunate to witness the mesmerizing Ganga Aarti‚Äîa captivating ceremony filled with chants, lights, and devotion. It‚Äôs an experience that truly captures the spirit of Varanasi.

The fun continued into the night as I explored the streets with friends, enjoying the vibrant night vibes of the city. Varanasi's street food is delicious, and I tried a variety of local delicacies, each bursting with flavor. The bustling lanes, with their night-time energy, were full of charm and excitement.

Overall, Darbhanga Ghat and the surrounding areas offer a perfect blend of peace, spirituality, and fun, making it an unforgettable visit for anyone looking to experience the essence of Varanasi.

Very near to the famous Dashashwamedh ghat of Banaras. A religious place with a holy significance.
I was here during end of February and as one can see the beauty of the ghats is quite eloquent.

Darbhanga Ghat, a serene oasis along the sacred Ganges, offers moments of tranquility and relaxation amidst the bustling energy of Varanasi. For a truly serene experience, I recommend visiting between 3-5 pm in the afternoon and after 11 pm in the evening.

During these hours, the ghat exudes a peaceful ambiance, allowing visitors to unwind and rejuvenate their minds. Simply sitting by the ghat, observing the ebb and flow of life along the river, can be a deeply calming experience.

Whether it's the gentle lapping of the water against the steps or the soft murmurs of conversations echoing in the distance, Darbhanga Ghat offers a respite from the hustle and bustle of the city. Take a moment to breathe, to observe, and to let your mind relax in the soothing embrace of this tranquil haven.

It's awesome and very good
The temple opens early at 4:00 AM and remains accessible until 11:00 PM.
The temple‚Äôs architecture and spiritual ambiance leave a lasting impression.

Darbhanga Ghat is a photogenic favorite! It's one of the most visually appealing, and architecturally impressive, ghats. It features an imposing palace hotel that you can stay in. It was built in the early 1900s by the royal family of Bihar. Adjoining it is Munshi Ghat, constructed in 1912 by Sridhara Narayana Munshi, finance minister of Darbhanga.

At Panchganga Ghat the travellers can witness the place where these five rivers meet and can also explore the various small temples nearby the ghat. Pancha Ganga Ghat in Varanasi is one of the most sacred ghats, featuring the famous and ancient Bindu Madhav temple. Unfortunately for us, when we visited from July 26th to 29th, the ghat was inaccessible due to incessant rains and high water flow from Prayagraj. All the steps were covered by somewhat muddy water.

This ghat has got its name from the confluence of five major rivers Yamuna, Saraswati, Dhutpapa, Kirana and the Ganges. Devotees from all across the world gather here to take a dip in the holy river Ganga. The Mosque of Alamgir is located close to the ghat, which was built by Aurangzeb.
It's nice ghat to take a dip and visit the kala bhairava temple, bindu madava temple and other temples as well.

You can visit the ghat walking through different ghats or you can reach through walking different world famous Gali( Lanes)
Peaceful ghat with good spots to take pictures and enjoy the view of Ganges and Other Ghats during the sunset.

sources.snippet: The Tulsi Ghat is worth a visit again one early morning to witness the Mud wrestlers. The day always starts with a short prayer session at the tiny altar inside the mud ring which is devoted to Lord Rama. Many men train here under the tutelage of doyen Siyaramji.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Tulsi Ghat in Varanasi is home to the Tulsi Manas Temple, known for safeguarding the Awadhi version of the Ramcharitmanas written by Tulsidas. Despite a theft of the manuscript in 2011, the temple remains a popular attraction. Nearby, visitors can access the Maharajas Ramnagar Fort and Museum via boat or pontoon bridge from Tulsi Ghat.

reviews.reviewText: From Tulsi Ghat, when you climb the stairs, at the end of the stairs, on the right, you eill find a small Hanuman Temple, which was established by Tulsi Das Behind the temple is a beautiful tree from where one can enjoy the view of Ganga and Tulsi ghat.

Tulsi Ghat in Varanasi is known for its serene and spiritual ambiance along the banks of the Ganges River. Visitors often find it less crowded compared to other ghats, making it a peaceful place for meditation and contemplation. The ghat is also famous for its connection to the renowned saint poet Tulsidas, adding a cultural and historical layer to the experience. Many people visit Tulsi Ghat for morning and evening rituals, boat rides, or simply to soak in the spiritual atmosphere. Overall, it's a recommended spot for those seeking a quieter and more reflective visit to Varanasi

The maddening rush of people doesn‚Äôt give one the mental peace after the Divya Darshan of Lord Vishwanath.

Tulsi Ghat is another ghat in Varanasi. Tulsi ghat is located near Assi ghat. It is named after poet Tulsidas. Tulsi ghat is relatively quiet place. One can either visit the ghat via lanes or can see this during the boat Ride.
The ghat is a perfect place for one to sit  and enjoy, especially in the evenings. One can sit at the ghat and watch the people going to different places while enjoying the serenity of the place. It's less crowded compared to assi ghat.
Also People can take baths here.
Nice place to visit.

placeMetadata.name: Varanasi Boat Ride and Cruise

sources.snippet: Highlights: Morning Boat Rides on the Ganges, Sunset Boat (Read More) Rides on the Ganga, Dev Deepavali Experience, Free Ashes Release, Candle & Flower Ceremony from the Boat, Tabla & Sitar Musicians on Your Private Boat, Exploring Varanasi's Alleys. A boat ride on the sacred Ganges is an integral part of the Varanasi experience, offering a surreal encounter with spirituality, rituals, and the historical charm of this ancient city. Whether you choose a sunrise voyage to witness the dawn rituals or a sunset cruise to immerse yourself in the mesmerizing nightly aarti fire ceremony, the Ganges unfolds its mystical tales.

sources.snippet: Boat Ride (1 hour, 300-500 rupees) ‚Äì The cost depends on your bargaining skills and the time you plan to embark. During puja and sunrise times, boats tend to be pricier.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Varanasi Boat Ride and Cruise offers a unique experience to explore the spiritual and historical charm of the ancient city. Whether you opt for a sunrise voyage to witness dawn rituals or a sunset cruise to immerse in the nightly aarti fire ceremony, the Ganges reveals its mystical tales. The experience includes opportunities such as Dev Deepavali, free ashes release, candle and flower ceremonies from the boat, and live music on private boats.

reviews.reviewText: The boat experience is truly divine. You can board a private boat or with the group the cost is nominal and it will give you a chance to visit all the ghats in Varanasi. It will also reduce your time If you want to travel from one ghat to other. We got a really great experience.

A boat ride on the Ganges is a MUST if you are in Kashi.
And if you want to see all the 'Ghats' from a distance, I guess the best place to start the boat cruise would be the 'Assi Ghat'.
I would suggest riding on a bigger boat and sitting on the upper deck to get a better view of the 'Ghats'.
I went for an early morning cruise to enjoy the lower temperature and cool breeze.
There are a total of 84 'Ghats' in Kashi, so keep counting üòÉ.
And if you have time and want to have a closer look and feel of the 'Ghats', I would suggest walking along the 'Ghats' from one end to the other. The total distance is about 6 km, which is quite doable. I did this in the late afternoon, but I guess it would be more pleasant if done early in the morning.
On many 'Ghats', you will find umpteen numbers of people taking 'holy' baths in the Ganges. So carry your bathing gear, just in case you also feel like taking a dip üòâ.
Of course, if you want to witness the 'Ganga Aarti', then the boat ride or walking has to be done in the evening.

Cruise ride and boating in evening in Ganga is a unique experience during Varanasi visit.
Enough boats are available there in sharing or separately.
While hiring a boat, bargaining is required and don‚Äôt forget to include a guide in hiring charges.
Better to go for boating in evening to see the beauty of all the Ghats and Ganga and watch GANGA AARATI.

A morning boat ride in Varanasi is¬†a memorable way to see the city's ancient ghats and experience the daily lives of locals.
A boat ride covering all ghats from Manikarnika to Assi or vice versa, is a must do activity while you are in Banaras. I would strongly recommend that you reach Assi Ghat by 5 am, enjoy the wonderful Ganga Aarti and then catch the shared boat at about 5:45 am. This boat will charge you Rs 50/100 per person, and offer the most amazing views of the ghats while you watch sunrise,Subah-e-Banaras, in parallel.This boat tour is combination of a boat ride and a walking tour of the southern part of the old city to explore the cultural diversity of Varanasi along with the oldest alive site in the whole Varanasi and a ‚ÄòAkhaada‚Äô¬†!!

We took a boat ride from Ahlyabhai Ghat. The boat ride started at 6PM. There were comfortable garden chairs on the upper deck. The ride took us around most of the ghsts and then banked opposite Dashashamedh Ghat so that we could see the evening Aarti of River Ganges. It's worth it. The charge for the hour and half bost ride is INR 200/- per head.

Incredible wonderful mind-blowing can't express in words, because some things in the world can't be said in words you just need to experience them,

The pics were taken during Ganga Aarti they might be little unclear but you can make out the place

We 14 members of a family booked Large Bazara on 20th Apr 2025. It was a Wonderful ride.... Good breifing by the staff. Taken us for evening ganga arathi. One of the best part of our tour to Varanasi.

Swami Viveknanda cruise from Alaknanda cruise was awesome. They cover all the ghats of Varanasi and we get to witness the Ganga Arati at Dashashwamedh ghat. Cost is Rs 1000. The cruise starts from Sant Ravidas ghat and drops back there itself. It
starts at sharp 5.30pm.

placeMetadata.name: Man Mandir Ghat

sources.snippet: At a distance of 5 km from Varanasi Junction, Man Mandir Ghat is a ghat on the banks of River Ganga in Varanasi. Situated just to the north of Dasashwamedh Ghat, it is one of the important ghats in Varanasi and also among the popular places to visit in Varanasi.Earlier known as Someswara Ghat, Man Mandir Ghat was built in 16th century CE by Raja Man Singh of Amer and was renamed after him. He also built a magnificent palace here and is known for its exquisite ornate window carvings.

sources.snippet: 4 km from city center 30 out of 43 Places To Visit in Varanasi. Manmandir Ghat was built by Maharaja Mann Singh in the early 17th century. placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Man Mandir Ghat, also known as Someshwara Ghat, is a stunning ancient ghat in Varanasi with remarkable Rajput architecture. Built over 400 years ago by Maharaja Man Singh, it features an impressive palace adorned with intricate carvings and stone balconies. The addition of the Jantar Mantar observatory by Sawai Jai Singh II in the 1730s adds a scientific dimension to the ghat.
placeMetadata.address: D31/178, Dashashwamedh Ghat Rd, Bhairavi ghat, Bangali Tola, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

reviews.reviewText:
Man Mandir Ghat, originally known as Someshwar Ghat, holds a rich history. It was built by Raja Man Singh of Amer in the 16th century, and the palace that stands on it is a beautiful example of Rajput-Mughal architecture. The ghat itself, with its broad stone steps, offers a tranquil space for pilgrims and visitors to connect with the holy Ganges River.
‚ÄãThe site is also a place of great scientific importance. Perched on top of the palace is an astronomical observatory, which was constructed by Raja Jai Singh II, a descendant of Raja Man Singh. This observatory, often referred to as Jantar Mantar, houses various masonry instruments designed to measure time and study celestial bodies.
‚ÄãThe Man Mandir Palace and its ghat are a visual spectacle, especially at night when the stone facade is illuminated, reflecting a serene glow on the river. The intricately carved windows and balconies, or jharokhas, add to the architectural grandeur. A stroll here provides a peaceful escape from the bustle of the city.
‚ÄãIn conclusion, Man Mandir Ghat is more than just a place for ritual bathing. It's a blend of spiritual devotion, architectural excellence, and scientific history. The palace and observatory stand as silent witnesses to centuries of tradition and innovation, making it a truly unique and enriching destination.

Raja Mansingh, the King of Amer in the 16th century, built the Ghat, along with a palace and a temple at the site. The Ghat is named after his surname, becoming known as Man Temple Ghat. In 1831, it was first mentioned by James Prinsep. Before that, it was called Someshwar Ghat until the 18th century.

This Ghat is notable for its large artistic palace and a place called Nakshatra Vaidhshala, which has both religious and cultural importance. The palace showcases the architectural styles of the Mathura Govardhan temple and the Rajasthani Rajput style from the North Medieval Period.

Raja Sawai Jai Singh, a descendant of Raja Mansingh, established the Nakshatra Vaidhshala in the 17th century, with plans made by a famous astrologer named Samrath Jagannath. Various astrological instruments, like Samrat Yantra and Naadi Valay Yantra, can be found in the Vaidhshala.

Man Mandir Ghat in Varanasi is a historically and architecturally significant site, well-regarded for its beautiful views of the Ganges and its historical structures. Built by Maharaja Man Singh of Amer in 1600 AD, the ghat features the Man Singh Observatory, also known as Jantar Mantar, which was added by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh II in 1710 AD. This observatory remains a fascinating spot for visitors despite its deteriorating condition. The ghat is renowned for its serene atmosphere, particularly during sunrise and sunset, making it an ideal place for photography and boat rides.

Man Mandir Ghat is a captivating blend of royal heritage, scientific curiosity, and spiritual grace‚Äîan often-overlooked jewel along Varanasi‚Äôs sacred riverfront. Built in the early 17th century by Raja Man Singh of Amber, this ghat is not only a place of devotion but also a testament to the architectural and intellectual pursuits of its time. Its sandstone fa√ßade, adorned with delicate carvings and arched balconies, reflects the elegance of Rajput and Mughal styles, offering a visual treat to those who appreciate historical depth.

What truly sets Man Mandir Ghat apart is the presence of the Man Mandir Observatory, perched atop the adjoining palace. This ancient astronomical center, equipped with instruments like sundials and celestial trackers, was once used to study the movements of stars and planets. It adds a fascinating scientific layer to the spiritual atmosphere, reminding visitors that Varanasi has long been a cradle of both faith and knowledge.

The ghat itself is serene and less crowded than its more famous neighbors, making it an ideal spot for quiet reflection. Pilgrims come here to perform rituals and offer prayers to the Ganga, while travelers often pause to admire the panoramic views of the river and the city‚Äôs skyline. The nearby temples‚Äîsuch as Rameshwara and Someshwara‚Äîadd to the sacred ambiance, creating a space where devotion and history coexist in harmony.

Man Mandir Ghat is a place where time seems to slow down. Whether you're watching the sunrise shimmer on the water, listening to the soft murmur of prayers, or exploring the observatory‚Äôs ancient instruments, the experience is both grounding and uplifting. It invites you to see Varanasi not just as a city of temples, but as a living museum of India‚Äôs spiritual and intellectual legacy.
Presents just besides Dashashwamedh Ghat.Mansingh Observatory(must visit,25 rupees tickets)situates inside the Man Singh place,one can take boat riding from here to witness all those iconic Ghats...

Manmahal Ghat, located along the Ganges River in Varanasi, is a historically significant and visually striking ghat. Manmahal Ghat was constructed in the late 16th century by Maharaja Man Singh of Amber (now Jaipur), a prominent king of the Mughal era and a general in Emperor Akbar's court. The ghat is known for its rich historical connections and architectural grandeur, reflecting the cultural and political interactions of the time.
The standout feature of Manmahal Ghat is the Manmahal Palace, which is an architectural marvel. The palace exhibits a blend of Mughal and Rajput architectural styles, with its intricate carvings, expansive balconies, and ornate windows. The palace's stone walls and large, elegant arches add to its majestic appearance. Today, the palace has been converted into an observatory and museum, attracting visitors interested in astronomy and history.

The ghat's previous name was Somesvara ghat. Manmandir Ghat is just beside the famous Dashashwamedh Ghat. It is named after the Manmandir Mahal, which is on the banks.

This ghat is an excellent location to make prayers and utilise the boating amenities. Ideal place to be in the evening for Ganga aarti.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Varanasi, a city steeped in vibrant culture and tradition, is known for its numerous festivals such as Ram Navami, Dussera, Deepawali, Holi, Hanuman Jayanti, and Chhath. The city's rich heritage is reflected in its monuments, ghats along the Ganges River, Banarsi sarees, handicrafts and narrow alleys. However, it is during Dev Deepawali that Varanasi truly comes alive.

reviews.reviewText: Dev Diwali¬†is a festival that should be captured in cameras to cherish memories of your celebration on the vivid Ghats of River Ganges.¬†Holy Voyages¬†offers you photography packages that could make your Dew-Diwali unique throughout life. You would have an eternal impression of your activities captured while performing cultural activities and rituals that you have assimilated after coming toVaranasi, the Holy City.

Dev Deepawali - a feast to the eye & soul, to witness the river Ganga ghats (in Varanasi) lit up with numerous diyas on Kartik Purnima every year. People all over flock together to witness this Light festival dedicated to the Gods. The Aarti is spectacular to watch performed by the priests on the shore of  river Ganga. Special ferry boats are available to glimpse the extravaganza closely down the river. It's a Festival to remember, to be  engraved in our memory lane. Visit to Believe it .....

Dev Diwali or Dev Deepawali is an auspicious day in Kartik, the seventh month in the Hindu calendar.¬†Dev Diwali¬†is often referred to as the "Diwali of Gods". Devotees do 'Kartik Snana' (holy dip) in the Ganges, light earthen lamps and pray to Lord Vishnu and Lord Shiva. This year, however, due to the COVID-19 pandemic 'Kartik Snana' will not be allowed in the Ganges in Haridwar, where lakhs of devotees from different parts of the country converge on Kartik Purnima. The ritual of 'Kartik Snana' is very significant for devotees.
Dev Diwali 2020 Date and Muhurat
Sunday, November 29Pradoshakal Dev Deepavali Muhurat - 5:08 pm to 7:47 pmPurnima Tithi begins at 12:47 pmPurnima Tithi ends at 2:59 pm on November.
""The Gods in the heaven celebrated Dev Deepawali on the Purnima Tithi of Kartik Shukla Paksha. And by doing so, they rejoiced the triumph of Lord Shiva over three demons named Tarakaksha, Kamalaksha and Vidyunmali. The three demons had created havoc and had disrupted the peace. Therefore, to restore Dharma and sanctity, Lord Shiva eliminated them with one arrow. This day is also known as Tripurari Purnima because Lord Shiva took the avatar of Tripurari to put an end to their tyranny. And to spread the message of peace and divinity, share the Happy Dev Deepawali¬†images, wishes, quotes, status messages and greetings below with your loved ones""

(Translated by Google) There is also Nandeshwar Ghat dedicated to Nandi, the vehicle of Lord Shiva. However, there are different beliefs regarding this. Some call it Nandeshwar Ghat and some recognize it as Nandishwar Ghat.
In the year 1940, Dwarikanath Chakraborty of Bhawanipur, Bengal got some major parts of the ghat concretely constructed and also built a huge building on the ghat bank. Nandishwar Shiva temple is established on the bank of the ghat itself, due to which it is believed that the ghat was named. The first mention about the ghat has been made by Motichandra in the book named 'Banaras and its Ghats'. At present the ghat is concrete and strong and mostly local people take bath here. In 1988, the Irrigation Department, with the help of the State Government, got the remaining unpaved part paved and the paved part repaired. This ghat also takes part in various events related to Ganga.

placeMetadata.name: Ramnagar Fort Varanasi

sources.snippet: Located across the Ganga River from Tulsi Ghat, it was built out of sandstone in AD 1750 on the orders of Raja Balwant Singh, the king of Banaras at the time. He and his descendants have lived in that fort for centuries now. In 1971, the position of an official king was abolished by the government, but still Pelu Bhiru Singh, is commonly referred to as the Maharaja of Varanasi.
sources.shortName: 19 Best Places to Visit in Varanasi 2024: Location, Timings

placeMetadata.description: Sandstone fort & royal residence with a museum that has vintage cars, costumes, an armory & more.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Ramnagar Fort Varanasi is a sandstone fort and royal residence that houses a museum featuring vintage cars, costumes, and an armory. The Mughal Era Fortification is a must-visit in the city of Varanasi. While there, visitors can also explore other historical sites such as Chunar Fort and the Bharat Kala Bhavan Museum.
placeMetadata.address: Varanasi Rd, Ram nagar, Ramnagar, Uttar Pradesh 221008, India

reviews.reviewText:
Great experience visiting this fort!
I absolutely loved it‚Äîthere are so many fascinating things to see, like the old kings' swords and other historical artifacts. The collection of vintage cars owned by the king was especially impressive. The environment is peaceful and adds to the charm of the place. A must-visit for history lovers!

It‚Äôs a stunning place to visit. You will learn the precious life of Indian Maharaja in the old days.  Life is full of faith, spiritual, luxury and legacy.

I am in love with the delicate design and attention to detail function and usage which demonstrate the styling and taste of the owner.

Photos are not allowed within the exhibition rooms but outside are ok.

The only recommendation I would add is to have a small refreshing corner to serve Indian tradition refreshing after a long walk.

The museum has great potential and some interesting exhibits. However, I would kindly suggest improving the cleanliness of the space and maintaining it more regularly. Also, due to high humidity, installing air conditioning would really enhance the comfort of visitors. These changes could make the experience much more enjoyable.

On a winter weekend this place is a perfect visit with a museum and ganga ghat view .. offers beautiful sunset scenes by the river Ganges . Has an entry ticket of Rs. 80 per adult. But the place has no parking.

The Ramnagar Fort could really use some maintenance  it felt like the place isn‚Äôt taken care of properly. A bit more cleanliness would definitely make a difference. There isn‚Äôt too much to explore inside, but the fort looks pretty nice from the outside and is good for taking photos. Overall, an okay experience but not something too revisit.

The fort is not maintained well. If you have time then you can visit else can skip, this place is a bit far from Vishwanath temple. Auto guy charged Rs 500/- to and from Golghar, better to travel if you have a taxi. Ticket charge is Rs 60/- for adult and Rs 20/- for children.

Ganga river can been from here but it was closed during my visit due to rise in water level.

It was a peaceful place. The museum inside had a collection of vintage items which belonged to the king who ruled during the British era .More than  half of the Fort is not open for tourists but still worth it

Entry fee adult rs 80
Foreigner fee rs 200
Police, Army, Central force, Student fee rs 20
Mobile photography not allowed üìµ
Other Information üìö
Ramnagar Fort is believed to have been built by Raja Suchet Singh, who died in 1844. His wife performed sati nearby. There is a Samadhi of Maharani at the site where the sati was performed. The fort was renovated and undertaken by the Archaeological Survey of India in 1972

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Shree Annapurna Mandir, also known as Annapurna Devi Mandir, is a renowned Hindu temple located near the Kashi Vishwanath Temple in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh. Constructed in 1729 AD by Maratha Peshwa Baji Rao, this temple holds significant religious importance and is dedicated to Goddess Annapurna Devi, the deity of nourishment.
placeMetadata.address: D 9, Annapurna Math Mandir, 1, Vishwanath Galli, Godowlia, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221001, India

reviews.reviewText: Shree Annapurna Mata mandir located inside the premises of Shree Kashi Vishwanath Mandir is one of the beautiful temple dedicated to Mata Annapurna i.e Mata Parvati. The main idol of Shree Annapurna Mata is very attractive and beautiful. Lots of other small temples are also inside this temple. By paying ‚Çπ100 per person you can go near  the feets of Mata Annapurna. Daily from morning 7 AM to night  10 PM free meals are served here. There are two units and each has different timing. The food is really very tasty and we must take this Prasad. If you pay some donation in the office you are given very beautiful foto of Mata Annapurna which can be laminated and kept at home. Do visit and take blessings of Mata Annapurna.

A serene and divine temple with a peaceful atmosphere.
The idol of Goddess Annapurna radiates grace and blessings.
Beautifully maintained premises with clean surroundings.
A perfect place to meditate and feel spiritually uplifted.
Staff and priests are kind and respectful.
A must-visit temple for every devotee in Varanasi!
You get prashad and also kashi vishwanath temple gopuram  top view (no use of electronic devices inside the dining area) Warning finishing what they give you from any breakfast lunch and dinner

My visit to the Annapurna Temple in Varanasi was absolutely incredible! The serene atmosphere, stunning architecture, and the divine presence of Goddess Annapurna made it a deeply spiritual experience. The vibrant rituals and warm hospitality added to the charm. A must-visit for anyone seeking peace and blessings!

Another of the most revered temples in Kashi. You have to reach by taking a narrow gully from the Vishwanath corridor and then relying on people's directions. As the name suggests, Maa Annapurna provides food free of cost three times a day, to all devotees visiting here. However, you're free to make donations to the trust.
Feel like heaven, and according to rituals have some rice from there.

Shree Annapurna Mandir is a peaceful and divine spot, right near Kashi Vishwanath. The temple is simple but spiritually uplifting.

They also serve free prasad/food, which feels special and humble. A nice stop for blessings and calm vibes amidst the busy city.

Varanasi is a city renowned for its spiritual significance and the presence of numerous temples. Varanasi is known for Vishwanath temple which is one of the Dwadash Jyotirlinga temples, Vishalakshi temple which is one of the Ashtadasha Shakti pitham. After Vishwanath temple and Vishalakshi temple the next famous temple of Varanasi is Annapurna temple which has significant importance and history.
The Annapurna temple is located near the Vishwanath temple on Dashaswamedh road, Vishwanath Galli. It is situated 15 meters North West of the Kashi Vishwanath mandir, 200 meters west of Vishalakshi temple.
The current Annapurna temple was built in 1729 A.D by the Maratha Peshwa Baji Rao. The temple is constructed in Nagara architecture and has sanctum with large pillared porch, which houses goddess Annapurna. The premises feature elaborate carvings, colorful decorations and traditional motifs, creating a spiritually uplifting atmosphere.

Interesting facts about Annapurna Devi temple:
1. The Devotees in Kashi believe that Kashi is the home of Goddess Annapurna, so no one ever sleeps hungry in this city. Devotees also believes that praying at this temple ensures prosperity, fulfilment of desires and protection from prosperity.
2. The main temple houses two idols of goddess, one made of gold and other of brass. The brass idol can be seen on any day whenever you plan your darshan and the gold idol can be only seen once a year on Annakut day which is celebrated every year on the fourth day of Diwali. Annakut is festival dedicated to expressing gratitude and thanksgiving to Goddess Annapurna.
3. Morning at 4 am Mangala Aarti gives to Maa Annapurna Devi. It's a serene soul stirring experience.
4. Kashi Annapurna Bojanalaya is located near the temple, which is charitable trust of the temple that provides free food to the devotees and visitors of Varanasi.

Temple Visiting timings:
Morning 04:00 am to 01:30 pm
Evening  04:00 pm to 10:00 pm

placeMetadata.name: Archaeological Buddhist Remains of Sarnath

sources.snippet: A short distance from Varanasi, Sarnath is a significant Buddhist pilgrimage site and an archaeological treasure. The ancient stupas, ruins, and serene gardens create a serene ambiance for photography. Explore the Dhamek Stupa, the Ashoka Pillar, and the Mulagandha Kuti Vihar for unique frames that showcase the spiritual aura of Sarnath.
sources.shortName: 11 Best Places For Photoshoot in Varanasi: Instagrammable Places

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Archaeological Buddhist Remains of Sarnath, located in the holy city of Varanasi, is a serene and well-maintained historical site. Visitors can explore the ancient Buddhist temples and immerse themselves in the peaceful ambiance. The entry fee for the site can be paid online, and there is also a nearby museum to visit. Engaging a knowledgeable guide can enhance the experience with insightful details about the site's storied past.
placeMetadata.address: 92JF+8RR, Rishpattan Rd, Sarnath, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221007, India

reviews.reviewText: Have been to this place a couple of times and it's one of my favorites places in kashi to unwind and relax, this place has great archeological significance. There are alot of tourists here majorly buddhist devotees. It is a must visit place, has a very great environment, hygiene and cleanliness.

Best place for history lover The Dhamekh Stupa in Sarnath is a truly awe-inspiring sight with massive structure, one of the four holy sites associated with Buddha's life (birth, enlightenment, first sermon, and death), marks the very spot where Buddha delivered his first sermon, setting the Wheel of Dharma in motion.
built by Emperor Ashoka in 249 BCE, the current stupa, constructed in the 5th century CE, has been restored several times. Its walls are adorned with intricate carvings of humans, birds, and ancient Brahmi script.

Exploring the ruins around the stupa offers a glimpse into the rich history of Sarnath. You can see remnants of ancient monasteries, monolithic railings, and the site of the Dhammarajika Stupa, which was unfortunately destroyed in the 18th century.

The ASI   has meticulously excavated the site, uncovering numerous inscriptions and artifacts, many of which are now on display in the museum opposite to the stupa complex.

The surrounding area is beautifully landscaped with lush greenery, providing a serene and peaceful atmosphere.

Don't forget to visit the Sarnath Deer Park nearby. The name "Sarnath" itself has a fascinating origin. It comes from "SƒÅrangnƒÅth," meaning "Lord of the Deer," referring to an ancient legend where the Buddha, in a past life, sacrificed himself to save a deer. This act of compassion inspired the king to create the park as a safe haven for these animals.

The Dhamekh Stupa is a must-visit for anyone interested in Buddhism and Indian history. It's a place where you can connect with the past, feel the spiritual energy of the site, and gain a deeper understanding of Buddha's teachings.

‚ú® Sarnath: A Hidden Gem of Serenity ‚ú®

Visiting Sarnath was one of the most peaceful experiences of my life. From the moment we entered, there was an unspoken calm in the air ‚Äî a kind of silence that speaks to your soul.

üßò‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Meditation here is on another level ‚Äî no noise, no disturbance, just the sound of nature and your own breath. It felt like time slowed down. The calmness truly helps you connect with yourself.

üåø The roads are incredibly clean, and the overall environment is well-maintained. You won‚Äôt see the usual city chaos here ‚Äî just peace, greenery, and the spiritual scent of history.

üê† What surprised me most was the beautiful fish in the ponds and water bodies around. They added such a refreshing vibe to the entire experience. Watching them swim calmly felt meditative in itself.

ü§ù The locals and staff are friendly and humble, always ready to help with a warm smile. It‚Äôs not just a place ‚Äî it‚Äôs an experience of kindness and spiritual simplicity.

If you're looking to escape noise and find inner peace, Sarnath is the place. Whether you're into spirituality, nature, history, or just need to clear your head ‚Äî this place heals you quietly.

10/10 ‚Äî Must Visit üåü

Very well maintained. Inside a big area with lots of different attraction. The ruins are driscribed properly in different sights. Would like to see a walking tour with clearly laid out directions. But overall a nice way of preserving and showing the ruins to the world. Great effort by archaeological department.

The Archaeological Buddhist Remains of Sarnath is a peaceful and beautiful place. It has old ruins, stupas, and historical structures related to Lord Buddha. The place is clean and well-maintained. placeMetadata.name: Pizzeria Vaatika Cafe

sources.snippet: Since its inception in 1993 as India's first authentic Italian Pizzeria, the cafe has been attracting tourists from all over the world. Set near the holy Assi Ghat of Varanasi, Pizzeria Vaatika Cafe is a big Italian surprise for many new travellers. It is a perfect place to escape from the hustle bustle of the back lanes of Varanasi and to enjoy the serene beauty of River Ganga.

placeMetadata.description: Humble, time-tested joint with a riverside patio for pizza & pasta, plus Indian & Chinese fare.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled on the tranquil banks of the Ganges at Assi Ghat, Pizzeria Vaatika Cafe is a charming eatery that seamlessly combines Italian flavors with an enchanting ambiance. This humble yet time-tested joint offers a delightful array of wood-fired pizzas and delectable apple pie, all prepared with utmost care and expertise.
placeMetadata.address: B-1/178, Assi Ghat Rd, Shivala, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221005, India

reviews.reviewText:
If you're at Varanasi and find yourself near Assi Ghat, Pizzeria Vatika Cafe is an absolute must visit. Nestled right on the Ghats with a serene view of the Ganges, the atmosphere here is both peaceful and vibrant a perfect blend of traditional charm and relaxed cafe vibes.
While their pizzas are quite popular, the real standout for me was their Apple pie with vanilla ice cream. It's honesty one of the best I've ever had. The pie is freshly baked with a butterly, flaky crustand warm spiced apples that taste homemade and comforting. Paired with a generous scoop of smooth vanilla ice cream, it's a dessert that hits every note: warm, cold, sweet and slightly tart.
Note- The waiting time is a lot(20-30min)  so be prepared for that.
Overall 5/5 for everything
Highly recommend- especially for dessert lovers ‚ù§Ô∏è

Exploring the vibrant streets of Banaras led us to a delightful gem on Assi Ghat. @pizzeriavaatika sits right on Assi, offering a serene and picturesque view of the Ganga River.
The experience was nothing short of magical, blending the rich cultural heritage of the city with mouth-watering flavors.

üî•Wood-Fired Oven Pizza: Crisp, smoky, and bursting with fresh ingredients. Each bite was a symphony of
flavors that transported us straight to Italy. IT
‚òïÔ∏èCoffee: Perfectly brewed, it was the ideal companion to our pizza indulgence. Smooth, aromatic, and just what we needed to kickstart our day.
üçùRavioli: Soft pillows of pasta filled with a delicious blend of cheese and herbs.
ü´ìCalzones: Golden, crispy pockets filled with savory goodness. Each bite was a delightful surprise, packed
with rich flavors and textures.
ü•ßApple Pies with Ice Cream: A sweet finale to our feast! Theywarm, spiced apple filling paired with creamy ice cream was pure bliss.

Should you find yourself in Banaras, I highly recommend visiting this pizzeria. Even if the food doesn‚Äôt entice you, the experience certainly will.

Good food with breathtaking views of the Ganges. We had a pizza and a pasta and both tasted nice. However, we found a hair in the apple pie which they promptly replaced. The second time too, same story, after which we dropped the idea of having apple pie altogether. The whatever little portion we had before the hair, tasted delicious though. Finding a seat during peak hours can be difficult, but we didn't have to wait long as two sweet English ladies agreed to share their table with us.

Nestled along Assi Ghat, Pizzeria Vatika Caf√© is a place where time slows down, the Ganga shimmers just steps away, and food feels like comfort.

What sets it apart in the bustle of Banaras is its serene, almost European charm that feels perfectly at home. In the mornings, as the staff readies for the day, the aroma of their legendary apple pie drifts from the oven. Golden, buttery, and flaky, it‚Äôs the kind of dessert that makes you smile before the first bite.

By evening, Vatika becomes a riverside trattoria. Thin-crust, wood-fired pizzas arrive fresh from the oven, simple and flavorful, never overdone. The handmade ravioli is delicate and rich, easily one of the best Italian dishes you‚Äôll find in this corner of India. And yet, with every bite, Banaras lingers in the background: temple bells, the river glowing at sunset.

The atmosphere seals the experience with open seating, a gentle river breeze, and just enough distance from the main road to feel peaceful. Service is unhurried, since everything is made fresh, but that‚Äôs part of its charm. The manager and staff are warm and welcoming, making it feel less like a caf√© and more like a home away from home.

Pizzeria Vatika Caf√© isn‚Äôt about flashy flavors or dramatic presentation. It‚Äôs about balance: Italy by the ghat, with Banaras always humming in the background. A little oasis in a city that never stops moving.

Must-tries: the signature apple pie, ravioli, and any of the wood-fired pizzas.

I recently visited Pizzeriaat Assi Ghat, and I was blown away‚Äîespecially by that riverside ambiance. The open-air setting perched above the Ganges, warmed by the glow of the evening aarti, makes it a uniquely soothing spot  Ôøº.

üçï Pizza & Pasta
The thin-crust pizzas are wood-fired to perfection‚Äîlight, crisp, and authentically Italian. I tried the Vaatika Special and Olive‚ÄëJalape√±o pizzas and loved how fresh and balanced the toppings tasted  Ôøº. Their pastas‚Äîboth red sauce and white cream‚Äîcome recommended; the white‚Äësauce penne is silky and veggie‚Äërich  Ôøº.

ü•ß Apple Pie
The apple pie with vanilla ice cream stole the show‚Äîwarm, tender, melt-in-your-mouth goodness. Many visitors rave it‚Äôs among the best they‚Äôve ever had  Ôøº.

üíÅ Service & Value
Service is friendly and relaxed, though peak times can bring slight delays. The open-air setting means occasional flies, especially in warmer months, but you‚Äôre paying for the vibe as much as the food. Prices are absolutely fair‚Äîaround ‚Çπ500 for two ().

üåø Final Thoughts
This place isn‚Äôt just another pizzeria‚Äîit‚Äôs an experience. Enjoying a wood-fired pizza and warm apple pie while gazing over the Ganges at sunset is simply magical. Ideal for travelers and locals alike looking for a calm, romantic, and delicious dining break along the ghats.

‚∏ª

Tips:
‚Ä¢	Go during the aarti for extra charm
‚Ä¢	Ask for the apple pie ‚Äì you can‚Äôt miss it
‚Ä¢	If you‚Äôre in a rush, maybe skip peak crowd times

Would definitely recommend it to anyone visiting Varanasi who wants a laid-back, memorable Italian meal by the river.

Designed particularily for parties and tourists, this place has sitting chambers for small parties with a tanle in between and an open rooftop cafe with traditional decorations and lighting. Bistro will give you a feel that you are on holidays. The waiters are quick to respond to and will assist you with the menu which is diverse basically in Continental and Italian. We ordered mushroom chilli, cheese nachos and a pizza. Mushroom chilli was a little bit on the spicy side and nachos were really amazing with a variety of sauce to eat with. The pizza arrived in the end and had a crispy base with fresh toppings. The prices are affordable and the ambience is amzingly bright, with lower volume music playing in the background. Ut is definetly a good place to hand around in the evening.

Best rooftop cafe, close to Assi ghat, try falafal & momos, my favourite from the cafe, mouth watering & best in class!!

New updates at the cafe Everytime I am visiting, they are innovating and coming with something new

Soya chap it was today Feb 2020, and change of infrastructure as well.

I tried American Soya Chap, which was awesome ‚ò∫Ô∏èüòä

Chole bhature and kulche's are also available now at very affordable prices üòäüòä

placeMetadata.name: Holy Chopsticks

sources.snippet: Getting authentic Chinese and Thai in Varanasi might have sounded weird five years ago, but today, Varanasi has one of the best spots for authentic Pan Asian dishes. Started by Grubhub, a house of leading restaurants in Varanasi, Holy Chopsticks is another step towards bringing all the global cuisines under one roof. The cafe aims to serve quality food using unique handcrafted recipes.
sources.shortName: Instagrammable cafes in Varanasi

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Holy Chopsticks is a popular restaurant in Varanasi, known for its Chinese and Thai cuisine. It caters to both vegans and non-vegans with a variety of dishes. While the prices may be on the higher side, many find it worth the cost. The restaurant offers hot and delicious Chinese food, including crispy Honey chicken (gravy), veg fried rice, veg noodles, butter garlic prawns, Cambodian style chicken curry, and chicken siu mai dimsums.
placeMetadata.address: S-17/317 Nadesar, Main Road, near Tandoor Villa, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221002, India

reviews.reviewText: Absolutely great  food, prompt service.... Never expected to get such delicious Holy chopsticks food was divine and the staff was very courteous.
Wide selection of cuisines. Sushi is a must try. Great ambiance with mellow music. The food is good with respect to quality and taste.

Holy chopsticks is at nadesar. It's on the main road. So the location is nice.
The ambience is perfect,  nice lighting and decor make it a good place to take pictures.
The restaurant is famous for its asian dishes.
sushi and dimsum are popular dish here. Both veg and non veg dishes are available. Wide selection of cuisine.
The staff service is very nice.
Especially the manager's behavior is especially nice.
They are courteous and service is fast.
On ocassion of their anniversary they are offering some offer depending on game of wheels.
Parking is not an issue here. Plenty of parking is available.
they charge 5% service tax. Which can be waived off.
Overall It's a nice place to eat asian cuisine.

Asian food is quite good, big portions.
Only sushi; not reach the standard yet.
Staff service is good

Holy Chopsticks has become my go-to spot for Indo-Chinese in Varanasi, and after six visits, I can confidently say‚Äîit never disappoints.

The service is quick, the ambience is warm and inviting, and the food is consistently delicious. Whether it‚Äôs the Thai green curry with rice or the veg ramen, every dish is packed with flavor and perfectly prepared.

It‚Äôs rare to find a place that hits the mark every single time, but Holy Chopsticks does exactly that. If you‚Äôre craving Indo-Chinese with a touch of class, this is the place to be.

One of the best places to have Chinese in the city. The dishes are a bit pricy but it's worth the taste.

We had  crispy Honey chicken( gravy ) which had ultimate taste but was a bit sweet.
Veg fried rice was properly cooked and was sufficient for two people.
Veg noodles was okay-okay, wasn't the best but still good.
Interior was totally Instagram -worthy and cozy.
The best was butter garlic prawns and Cambodian style chicken curry.
Even chicken siu mai dimsums were amazing.

I am a regular at this place but this time I was really disappointed. Service was really pathetic. I had received a 13 ear anniversary coupon from the restaurant itself and I informed the server to redeem at the time of placing order. After that my order was delayed for a long time and when it came the server just went without even an attempt to serve. While he was serving the other customers. On pointing it out that if you add service charge on your bill ,u are supposed to serve also he was unapologetically rude. Pathetic experience. I don't think I want to eat here again if this is the service provided

The ambience is decent, the staff was polite and well behaved, they recommended good dishes. Good for hanging out with family and friends. Accecible location. The food was good and we really enjoyed dimsum, pan fried noodles, Korean barbecue chicken. We did not like the sizzler and mocktails (too much sugar syrup).
I recommend booking to get a good table.

placeMetadata.name: Cafebility, Vinayak Plaza

sources.snippet: It is a social initiative taken up by some to offer help to the disabled community to hone social and communication skills in the hospitality sector and become self-dependent. It provides, "an accessible, dynamic and safe learning environment" for its target group. This initiative has also helped in raising general awareness among people of Varanasi.
sources.shortName: Instagrammable cafes in Varanasi

placeMetadata.address: Shop No. 09, 2nd Floor, Vinayak plaza, Maldahiya, Chetganj, Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh 221002, India

reviews.reviewText:
As far as "travel weary westerners" arriving in Varanasi, it was a delight to stumble across this little cafe/restaurant located on the second floor of the plaza building.
What made it exceptional?
Two things really....
A place offering young, disabled Indians the opportunity to gain a skillset in hospitality that will hopefully make their lives richer.
Possibly the best coffee we've had in 2 months of travel! Nearly as good as from a serious Melbourne barista!
If you are in need of a decent caffeine fix, come and support this little institution. You'll feel good in more ways than you expect
Having recently retired from 30 years in hospitality, I can recommend Cafebility completely!
Maybe just remember that it is a learning environment too, so a little patience may be needed..   üòå

Though it's a great initiative, my experience here was not great at all. I ordered a shake and was quietly sitting, charging my phone. The place was completely empty the entire time. It was scorching heat but they hadn‚Äôt even turned on the air conditioning. After about an hour, without any crowd or rush, I was asked to leave for not placing an additional order.

While I understand cafes may have policies, the approach felt unwelcoming, especially considering I was a paying customer and wasn‚Äôt occupying space during peak hours. Would have appreciated a bit more hospitality and flexibility. Unfortunately, not a place I‚Äôd return to.

We found this amazing cafe on our first day in Varanasi.  I advise everyone to come here.  you will find delicious food, reasonable prices and excellent service here.  I especially liked the fact that this is a conceptual place and it gives people with disabilities the opportunity to express themselves.  I wish development and prosperity to this place

Delicious food, nice coffee, hospitable and cosy place. It is really hard to find zero spicy options in India, and these guys made our food exactly what we ask (for our fragile European stomachs). Also the restaurant is really clean. Thank you. üôèüåç‚úåÔ∏èüíúüòéüåª

The food and service was good but since the place was at the corner of the building it was getting direct sunlight. We asked the staff to switch on both the ACs so that it cool down the atmosphere but they denied.

When we asked to switch on the AC they said they'll do if we order in the meantime, they got us placing the order before or else we would have left the place.

Not recommended!

Tried their Chicken sausage sandwich which was appetising and really well prepared..Open Panini's which was their chef's special is something new and a must try..The way it is prepared , the flavour, the cheese , everything was in right amount and complimented each other....Ambience is quite casual and good to sit and have a convo over coffee or any other food stuff...Prices are extremely reasonable and pocket friendly...Worth the visit...

Cafebility is one of the finest and cleanest place in varanasi which is situated near maldahiya crossing. Fully neat and clean place with peace and silence. If you want to eat something delicious with peace  then please go to Cafebility. The place is of decent size and cozy, the food was pretty good, the prices were not too expensive nor too cheap so it's balanced.I was hoping there would be specially abled waiters here but I didn't see any. Services are little slow but that's ok. You can use this time for calm your mind and for stability and for use your phone or look around to see the beauty of this place. Overall a good experience. I gave you 4 out of 5 Cafebility.
Had a lovely time at Cafebility. I really enjoyed the music and drinks!

ops.insert: Sarnath is a town northeast of Varanasi, in Uttar Pradesh, India. As the Lalitavistara sutra states, the Gautama Buddha chose "Deer Park by the Hill of the Fallen Sages, outside of Varanasi" for his first teaching after he attained enlightenment in Bodh Gaya. The teaching is entitled Dhammacakkappavattana sutra. Wikipedia.
Bustling riverside steps down to the Ganges River, used for religious rituals daily.

place.name: Bharat Kala Bhavan Museum, BHU Varanasi

ops.insert: University museum focused on art & archeology, with sculptures, paintings, jewelry, textiles & more.
Landmark riverside temple to Shiva, known for its 18th-century gold-plated spire and sacred well.
One of the city's oldest ghats, this iconic site is a storied spot for traditional Hindu cremations.
One of Asia's largest residential university's with a campus stretching over a 5km area.

place.name: Shri Satyanarayan Tulsi Manas Mandir, Varanasi

ops.insert: Stately Hindu temple with white marble construction, landscaped gardens & numerous engravings.
One of the city's oldest ghats, this iconic site is a storied spot for traditional Hindu cremations.

The Ghats of Varanasi are a series of broad, centuries-old steps following the banks of the Ganges River, where sacred Hindu ceremonies are held daily. Dashashwamedh Ghat is known for its colorful aarti, a nightly fire ritual with bells and chanting, while sunrise yoga sessions are hosted at neighboring Assi. Some ghats are backed by imposing palaces, and others, like Manikarnika Ghat, are sacred cremation sites.
Commissioned by an exiled 19th-century Nepalese king, this terracotta temple is dedicated to Shiva.
18th-century fortress-style palace with a terrace overlooking the river & stairs to the water.
Circular stone 43m-tall Buddhist shrine with bird & script carvings, dating back to 500 CE.
Imposing sandstone palace with towering Greek pillars & turrets, with a Shiva temple & a hotel.
Landmark ghat & religious site for spiritual bathing, prayer & holiday festival events.
These riverfront steps named for Queen Ahilyabai are a destination for religious bathing rituals.
Humble, time-tested joint with a riverside patio for pizza & pasta, plus Indian & Chinese fare.
Sandstone fort & royal residence with a museum that has vintage cars, costumes, an armory & more.
Serene Buddhist temple complex featuring a whimsically painted shrine interior & art.

headerTemplate.blurbTemplate: Many of us love traveling on the Wanderlog team, so naturally we‚Äôre always on the hunt to find the most popular spots anytime we travel somewhere new. With favorites like [examplePlaceNames] and more, get ready to experience the best places in [geoNameWithThe].
headerTemplate.topBlurb:
Varanasi, one of the oldest living cities in the world, is a mesmerizing tapestry of spirituality, culture, and history. As you wander through its narrow lanes, the scent of incense mingles with the sounds of chanting and the gentle flow of the Ganges River. This city is not just a pilgrimage site; it‚Äôs a vibrant canvas waiting to be captured through your lens. From the golden spires of the Shri Kashi Vishwanath Temple to the serene beauty of the Assi Ghat, every corner of Varanasi tells a story that beckons to be photographed.

For photography enthusiasts, Varanasi offers a plethora of stunning backdrops that range from the bustling ghats to the tranquil temples. Imagine capturing the ethereal glow of the evening aarti at Dashashwamedh Ghat or the intricate carvings of the Shri Satyanarayan Tulsi Manas Mandir. Each location, whether it‚Äôs the historic Ramnagar Fort or the peaceful Panchaganga Ghat, provides a unique perspective on the city‚Äôs rich heritage. So grab your camera and get ready to explore the best photo spots that Varanasi has to offer, where every snapshot is a glimpse into the soul of this enchanting city.
